Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des produits cosmétiques, elle fait ce commerce depuis  près de 6 ans déjà ce qui lui a permis d’avoir une parfaite maîtrise de son activité. Elle exerce ce commerce au marché local de hedzranawoé et dans ce marché elle a des concurrentes, pour mieux vendre et faire face à la concurrence elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 1 cartons de crème ; 5 cartons de perruques, 20 mèches de différents modèles, des parfums et divers.
Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, avec son revenu elle contribue aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady earns a living selling cosmetics. She has been in this business for almost 6 years already, which means she knows a lot about this line of work. She sells her wares in the local market of Hedzranawoé, and in this market, she has competitors. In order to make more sales and deal with the competition, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 1 carton of crèmes, 5 boxes of wigs, 20 hair extensions of various sorts, perfumes and other items.

She is married and the mother of 3 children. With her income she contributes to supporting the family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Lukaya

texts.en:
Lukaya K. trades in printed textiles – java, fancy, wax, etc. She hawks to sell and also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Lukaya has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

Lukaya is 30 years old, married and has two children: a boy and a girl. Both are currently in primary school. Her husband repairs watches. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Lukaya wants to expand her business and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy textiles

loans.name: Akoété

texts.fr: Monsieur A. exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail des cartes de recharges MOOV, TOGOCEL et ILLICO,il fait ce commerce de façon ambulante. la vente de carte de recharge est très développée à Lomé, cela est dû à  l’existence de plusieurs sociétés de téléphonie. Dans son quartier il est le seule à exercer cette activité ce qui constitue encore un plus pour lui. Sa clientèle grandit, pour mieux les satisfaire, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 02 cartons de cartes ILLICO, 04 cartons de cartes TOGOCEL et 02 cartons de cartes MOOV.
texts.en:
Mr. A. earns his living retailing phone cards for MOOV, TOGOCEL et ILLICO. He sells his phone cards on foot, door-to-door. The sale of phone cards is widespread in Lomé, due to the existence of several phone companies. In his neighborhood, he is the only one in this line of work which is an advantage for him. His clientele is growing and so that he can better satisfy them, he is asking WAGES for a loan to buy two boxes of Illico phone cards, 4 boxes of Togocell cards, and 2 boxes of Moov cards.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of phone cards for resale

loans.name: Koténa

texts.fr: Ce monsieur a ouvert sa propre boutique dans laquelle il fait de la photocopie et des traitements de texte, il y a également ouvert une cabine téléphonique, après étude de besoins il a veut ouvrir une autre boutique dans un autre quartier, pour réaliser cela il s’adresse à WAGES et demande un autre crédit pour acheter une autre machine à copier et s’installer.
texts.en:
This gentleman has opened his own shop where he does photocopying and word processing. He has also opened a phone booth. After surveying the needs of the community, he wants to open a second shop in a different neighborhood and is asking WAGES for a loan to buy another photocopier so he can set up that shop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a photocopier

loans.name: Namana

texts.fr:
Cette  femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  chaussures, elle fait ce commerce dans le marché local de hedzranawoè, elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Vu la situation géographique de son activité elle réalise de bonnes recettes tous les jours, actuellement elle veut agrandir son activité et vendre plus. Pour se faire elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 70 chaussures de grande qualité. 
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman earns her living selling shoes. She sells them in the local market of Hedzranawoè. She buys her inventory in the big open-air market of Lomé. In view of the location of her business, she has a good turnover every day. Presently, she wants to expand her business and sell more. For that reason, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 70 pairs of high quality shoes.

She is married and the mother of 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes for re-sale

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 05 enfants, elle réside dans le quartier d’adidogomé avec sa famille. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes. Elle exerce son commerce dans son quartier et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Actuellement elle veut attirer de nouveaux clients afin d’augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire de tous les jours, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 15 pagnes HITARGET de haute qualité et 15 pagnes VLISCO.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of 5 children. She lives in the Adidogomé neighborhood with her family. She earns a living selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly patterned African cloth). She sells in her neighborhood and buys her inventory in the big open-air market of Lomé. Presently, she wants to attract new customers so as to earn more money daily, so she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 15 high-quality Hitarget brand "pagnes" and 15 Vlisco brand "pagnes".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes" for resale

loans.name: Brillantes De Tascana Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Brillantes de Tacsana esta ubicado en la comunidad de Tacsana, distrito de Yauli, provincia de Huancavelica.

Hilda, es casada y tiene 02 hijos pequeños ella se dedicó a tejer mantas y similares debido a que su esposo, tuvo un accidente en la mina donde trabajaba. Ahora que puede acceder a capital, utiliza materiales de mejor calidad y ya cuenta con una maquina de bordar. Su meta es tener una fabrica textil, para la cual ya esta ahorrando.

Nancy se dedicaba a vender granos y tejidos en su comunidad, los cuales ahora gracias a contar con un préstamo traslada Lima para su venta, de esta manera incrementando sus ventas y el crecimiento de su negocio. Esta ahorrando para abrir una bodega, la cual llevará el nombre de su hijo.

Julia, es feriante desde muy joven, vende artesanía textil y con sus préstamos incrementa cada vez mas su mercadería. Aunque aun no ha podido llevar sus productos a la capital, no se desanima. A ella le gustaría tener una empresa su propia empresa de tejidos.
texts.en:
The Village Bank Brillantes de Tacsana Group is located in the Tacsana community, Yauli district, Huancavelica province.

Hilda is married and has two small children. She started embroidering blankets and similar items due to an accident her husband had at the mine where he worked. Now she can make a living, use materials of the best quality, and have an embroidery machine. Her goal is to have a textile factory, for which she is already saving up.

Nancy sells grains and embroideries in her community. Thanks to a loan she has been able to increase her sales by moving to Lima, thereby growing her business. She is saving up her money to open a store, which will bear the name of her son.

Julia, a saleswoman since youth, sells artisan textiles has been increasing her merchandise with each loan. Although she has not been able to bring her products to the capital yet, she is not discouraged. She would like to eventually have her own embroidery company.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase materials

loans.name: Santa Rosa De Matipacana Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Santa Rosa D. Matipacana, se encuentra localizado en un Anexo del Distrito D. Yauli, localidad rodeada D. cerros, quebradas y plantaciones D. eucaliptos. Esta comunidad dentro D. sus principales actividades se caracteriza por su artesanía y ganadería.

Isabel, es casada y tiene 04 hijos, elL. se dedica a L. crianza y venta D. cerdos y vacunos negocio con el cual educa a sus hijos y por lo cual se siente orgullosa. Con su préstamo adquirirá cerdos D. raza y en el futuro le gustaría tener un gran granja y dedicarse a L. porcicultura.

Hilda, desD. muy niña aprendió a bordar y tejer, actividades a las que se dedica actualmente y con las cuales pagó su educación. Hilda, se encuentra ahorrando para implementar un taller artesanal.

Lidia es soltera y sin hijos, elL. tiene una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes, L. cual provee con nuevos productos cada vez que recibe un préstamo. Su meta, es llegar a tener una tienda granD. y surtida y seguir ahorrando, para que cuando tenga hijos no les falte nada.
texts.en:
The Village Bank Santa Rosa D. Matipacana adjoins the district of Yauli, a town surrounded by hills, streams and eucalyptus plantations. The primary activities of this community are artisanship and cattle farming.

Isabel is married with four children. She raises and sells pigs and cattle, a business through which she has educated her kids, something that she is proud of. With her loan she will purchase pigs and in the future she would like to have a large farm to rear them.

Hilda learned to embroider and sew when she was a little girl, activities she still does and which have paid for her education. Hilda is looking to save her money to set up an artisanal workshop.

Lidia is single without kids and has a small grocery store, which provides customers with new products every time she receives a loan. Her goal is to eventually have a large, well-stocked store and continue saving so that when she has kids they will not go without.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise, cattle, and raw materials for their businesses

loans.name: Clara

texts.es:
Clara es socia del Bancomunal Antares.
Clara es  de Piura, enviudo hace diecinueve años, tiene 70 años, cinco hijos todos mayores y son profesionales.
Clara empezó vendiendo abarrotes en sus casa, hasta que se dio una oportunidad  de comprar un puesto en un mercado, lo compro con la ayuda de sus hijos y los  ahorros que tenia,  se puso  a vender abarrotes desde hace  27 años 
Desde que Clara esta en Finca ha sido una ayuda para crecer en  su negocio, ha recibido charlas las cuales han ayudado  ha organizarse y atender mejor a las clientas.
Clara necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles,  para la compra de sacos de arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos.
El sueño de clara es salir adelante para ayudar a sus hijos a surgir.
texts.en:
Clara is a member of the Antares Community Bank. She is from Piura, a widow for nineteen years, 70 years old, with five children, all grown and professionals. Clara began selling groceries from her house until there was an opportunity to buy a stall in the market. She bought it with the help of her children and the savings she had. She has been selling groceries for 27 years. Since Clara has been in FINCA it has been a help to expand her business. She has attended talks that have helped with organization and to give better service to her clients. Clara needs a loan of 1200 soles for the purchase of sacks of rice, sugar, milk, and noodles. Clara's dream is to get ahead in order to help her children advance.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sacks of rice, sugar, milk, noodles

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa es socia D. Bancomunal Antares
Rosa es  conviviente,  tiene 57 años, no tiene hijos 
Rosa tenía una tienda pero la cerró por que no vendía mucho por la zona donde esta, con su hermano empezó a ofrecer servicio de movilidad, a  repartir cartas y entregar paquetes   
Desde que Rosa esta en Finca  aprendió ahorra, a ser cumplida y ordenada en su negocio,  
Rosa necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de llantas y batería 
El sueño de Rosa es comprar un carro con asiento especial  para su hermano que es minusválido
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of Bancomunal Antares. She is 57 years old, has a partner but no children. Rosa had a shop that she closed due to low sales because of the area where it was located. She started a courier service with her brother, they deliver letters and packages. Rosa has learned to save and to be organized since she started with Finca. She is asking for a loan of $350 to buy tires and a battery .Rosa's dream is to buy a car with a special seat for his brother who is disabled.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tires and a battery

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza es socia del Bancomunal Antares.
Maritza es madre soltera, tiene 40 años,  dos  hijos de 11 y 8 años  que están en la escuela estatal.
Maritza   es de Cerro de Pasco, solo estudio primaria,  después de trabajar en casas, junto con su mamá se dedicaron  a dar desayunos por las  mañanas en una playa de estacionamiento  por la avenida Brasil, actualmente Maritza se ha hecho cargo del negocio sus hijos la ayudan, y por las tardes vende panchos y anticuchos en la puerta de su casa. en Villa el Salvador. 
Desde que Maritza esta en Finca, ha sido de mucha ayuda, su economía ha mejorado, su negocio creció.  
Maritza necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de queso, leche, jamonada.  
El sueño de Maritza es tener un restaurante.
texts.en:
Maritza is a member of Bancomunal Antares.

Maritza is a 40-year old single mother of two children, aged 8 and 11, who attend public school.

Maritza is from Cerro de Pasco. She studied at a primary level only. After working in houses with her mother, they started supplying breakfasts in the morning at a car park on Avenida Brasil. Now Maritza is in charge of the business. Her children help, and in the afternoons they sell hot dogs and kebabs out of their home in Villa El Salvador.

Since Maritza has been with Finca, they have been a great support. Her finances have improved, and her business has grown.

Martiza needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy cheese, milk and canned ham.

Maritza’s dream is to have a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cheese, milk and canned ham

loans.name: Victor Fernando

texts.es:
Víctor es socio del Bancomunal Antares
Victor es casado tiene  44 años, dos hijos de 12 años, son gemelos, que están estudiando en la escuela estatal. 
Victor estudio para electricista, trabajo por varios lugares como maestro electricista  hasta que se decidió trabajar en su casa, pudo en la puerta de su casa un cartel  que decía maestro electricista  y lo van a buscar para que realice trabajos en casas, oficinas y edificios.    
Desde que Victor esta en Finca, para el es mucho mas sencillo trabajar porque los prestamos son un respaldo y no anda angustiado.
Victor necesita un préstamo de 600 soles para la compra de cables de corriente, de diferentes grosores, empalmes, cintas aislantes  
El sueño de Víctor es  abrir una pequeña empresa de servicio al publico de electricidad, gasfiteria,
texts.en:
Victor is a member of the Antares Microfinance Institute.

He is a 44-year-old married father with 12-year-old twins who attend state school. Victor studied to become an electrician. He worked at various places as a master electrician, until he decided to work from home. He put up a sign on his door that read “Master Electrician,” so people now seek his services for homes, offices and buildings.

Ever since Victor has been a member of Finca, it is so much easier for him to work because the loans are support for him, and he is not distressed.

Victor needs a 600.00 PEN loan so that he can purchase power cables of varying thicknesses, wire splices, and electrical tape. Victor dreams of opening his own electrical and plumbing company.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase power cables, wire splices, and electrical tape

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: Juan acaba de cumplir 35 años, desde hace 15 años vive con amada pareja que le dio 2 hijos, quienes son el motivo de su esfuerzo; actualmente viven en su casa propia.  De pequeño apoyaba a sus padres en los trabajos agrícolas, desde entonces ha ido aprendiendo las técnicas de la agricultura y cuando formó su propia familia comenzó a cultivar cítricos y café, los cuales trabaja con el valioso apoyo de su esposa. Adicionalmente, hace como 6 meses se viene dedicando al servicio de taxi, desde las 6.00am hasta las 6.00pm, por ello le pagan 20 soles diarios y los fines de semana trabaja hasta las 11 de la noche en aras de acumular mayores ganancias para la mantención de su familia. Pero durante los meses de cosecha de café deja de lado su trabajo como conductor y se dedica netamente a la recolección para evitar perder los frutos de café tan valiosos para su familia. Juan se siente muy a gusto con sus siembras y mientras trabaja con el carro piensa en sus cultivos, ya que alguna vez ha sido víctima de robos debido a su ausencia. Por ello que su esposa trata de acudir a sus chacras constantemente para cuidar ser frutos, puesto que cuando los comercializa obtiene buenas ganancias, de ahí que sus anhelos son de incrementar sus cultivos de café. Este es su 5to préstamo consecutivo que viene trabajando con MFP, cumpliendo todos los pagos en las fechas programadas. Juan tiene un sobre nombre muy gracioso, es cual siempre es motivo de risa para sus compañeros de banco comunal, le dicen “la gorda bella”. El dinero solicitado lo invertirá en tramitar su licencia de conducir en la municipalidad de su localidad, con el resto del dinero comprará fertilizantes químicos para el abonado de sus siembras de café.
texts.en:
Juan just turned 35. He has lived with the beloved mother of his two children for 15 years. They are the motivation for his efforts. They currently live in their own house. Since he was little he helped his parents in the agricultural work. From then on he was learning farming techniques. When he formed his own family he started planting citrus and coffee. He does this with his wife’s valuable help. Also, six months ago he started driving a taxi from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. They pay him 20 PEN a day. On the week ends he works until 11 at night plowing in order to get greater income to support his family. During the coffee harvesting months he leaves aside his work as a driver and works on gathering his harvest to avoid loosing the coffee beans, which are so valuable for his family. Juan feels very pleased with his farming, and while he is driving in his car he thinks about his crops. One time he was robbed because he was not there. Because of that his wife tries to go to the fields constantly to take care that they bear fruit. When the crop is sold, he gets very good earnings. His goal is to increase his coffee crop. This is his fifth consecutive loan working with MFP. He makes all of his payments on time. Juan has an amusing nickname, which is always the cause for laughter with his colleagues in his community bank. They call him the “the big beauty”. The money he is asking for is to process his driver’s license in the local town hall. With the rest of the money he will buy chemical fertilizers to fertilize his coffee fields.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay to process his driver's license and buy fertilizers

loans.name: Tayepsu Group

texts.en:
This is Hassan K., Kali K. and Aminata K.. They call their group Tayepsu. They are all local entrepreneurs based in Magburaka Town, northern Sierra Leone. This is the very first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profit and consequently improve on their standards of living.

Hassan K. (left) is the leader of this group. He was born in Magburaka Town thirty-five years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have three children. One is in primary school and the others are still not of school-going age.

Hassan is a motorbike rider; motorbikes are widely used in Sierra Leone as taxis. He has been in this motorbike business for seven years now, among the very first to start the business in Magburaka Town. With this loan, together with the little he has been saving, Hassan would like to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa es una mujer de 49 años, enviudó hace 20 años, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 4 hijos, quienes son el motivo de su trabajo y esfuerzo. A las 4.00am ya está despierta preparando la comida para su casa y desde las 8.00am trabaja en sus chacras quitando las malezas y arbustos de sus frutos cítricos. Cuando termina con sus propias tierras trabaja en la chacra de sus vecinos donde le pagan entre 13 y 15 soles diarios, dinero que utiliza para cubrir las necesidades inmediatas de sus hijos. Algunas veces su trabajo lo realiza con el apoyo de sus hijos para terminar en menor tiempo su contrato. A Rosa los trabajos agrícolas le causan gran placer y satisfacción, ya que mediante una buena cosecha acumula buenas ganancias que le permiten alimentar y educar a sus hijos. Por ello, ahora Rosa tiene planes de incrementar sus terrenos agrícolas para que sus hijos los trabajen. Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, donde no ha tenido dificultades de pago y para este nuevo préstamo se compromete a cumplir igual como en los ciclos anteriores. El dinero solicitado lo piensa invertir en la compra de 10 sacos de guano de corral y con el resto  comprará de 6 sacos de urea para abonar sus cítricos.
texts.en:
Rosa is 49, and she has been a widow for 20 years. She lives in her own house together with her four children. Her children are her motivation for her effort and work. At 4:00 a.m. she is up and preparing the food for her house. From 8:00 a.m. on she works in her fields weeding and collecting the citrus fruit. When she finishes with her own land she works on her neighbor’s farm. They pay her between 13 and 15 PEN a day. She uses this money to cover the immediate necessities of her children. Sometimes her children help her finish her contracted work in less time. Agricultural work gives Rosa great pleasure and satisfaction. A good harvest brings good earnings, which allow her to feed and educate her children. Rosa has plans to increase her farming land so that her children can work on it. This is her fifth loan with MFP. She has not had difficulty making payments. She promises to repay this loan the same as she did with the previous loans. She plans to use the money she is asking for to buy ten sacks of farm manure. With the rest of the money she will buy six sacks of urea to fertilize her citrus.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es: Vilma tiene 39 años, tiene 3 hijos que viven junto a ella en su casa propia. Hace varios años atrás se dedicaba a la venta de tamales, en este negocio le iba muy bien, con lo que terminó de construir su casa y educar a sus hijos. Pero tras las lluvias constantes del invierno pasado se generaron derrumbes provocando deslizamientos de tierras y perjudicando la parte donde estaba su cocina de leña. Desde entonces ya no prepara tamales, optó por la venta de buñuelos cobrado 1 sol por porción. A Vilma le gusta su trabajo por eso que a partir de las 6 de la tarde está ubicada al costado del puente Paucartambo hasta 9 o 10 de la noche, por ser un  lugar muy transitado por sus vecinos y pobladores de otras zonas aledañas. Vilma ameniza sus ventas con su buen carácter lo que le ha permitido captar mucha clientela, ya que en 3 meses logró que su negocio le sea muy rentable y con estas ganancias espera volver a implementar el espacio que tenía para la venta de tamales, lo cual haría por las mañanas y en las tardes continuaría con sus buñuelos acompañados con miel. Este es el quinto préstamo consecutivo que viene trabajando con MFP, Vilma es muy  responsable con sus cuotas y no le gusta pagar fuera de tiempo; es por eso que anima a sus compañeros de banco comunal para que no paguen a último momento. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de harina y aceite, ingredientes básicos para la preparación de los buñuelos.
texts.en:
Vilma, 39, lives together with her three children in her own house. She has been selling tamales for several years. Because this business went very well for her, she finished building her house and can educate her children. But, the constant rains last winter caused erosion, which cause landslides that damaged the area where her wood stove was. Since then she does not make tamales. She chose to sell “buñuelos” (fritters). She charges one PEN per portion. Vilma likes her work. At six in the evening she is at the side of the Paucartambo bridge until nine or ten at night. It is an area which is heavily traveled by her neighbors and residents of nearby zones. Vilma brightens up her sales with her good character, which has allowed her to get many customers. In three months she was able to make her business very profitable. With these earnings she hopes to return to the space she had set up to sell tamales. She would sell tamales in the morning, and in the afternoons she would continue to sell her buñuelos with honey. This is her fifth consecutive loan working with MFP. Vilma is very responsible with her payments; she does not like to make a late payment. She encourages her colleagues in her Community Bank to not pay at the last minute. The money she is asking for is to buy flour and oil, which are the basic ingredients in making her buñuelos.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for he buñuelos

loans.name: Las Perlas Group

texts.es:
Irene H. es una señora de 24 años, casada con 2 hijos. Ella vive en una localidad llamada El Recreo, a 2 horas del Puerto de Veracruz la cual es un poblado que se dedica principalmente a la siembra de Arroz, Pepino, Sandia, Melon y Tomate.

Doña Irene se dedica principalmente a la venta de ropa para dama, adicionalmente a esto vende utencilios de plastico para la cocina. Estas ventas las hace en su localidad con sus vecinos y familiares. Ella solicita el credito ya que compra la ropa en otra ciudad y necesita el prestamo para comprar la mercancia y el traslado a la ciudad donde la compra. 

La meta de la señora es poder construir en un futuro un local frente a su casa para tener ahi su mercancia. Y asi poder ayudar a su esposo y poder brindarles un mejor futuro a sus hijos.

Doña Irene es la representante de un Grupo llamado Las Perlas, el cual esta conformado por 4 mujeres. Las cuales se dedican entre otras actividades a la venta de refresco, venta de calzado por catalogo y corte de pelo. 

Por ello solicitan un credito de $20,000 para poder invertir en sus actividades economicas.
texts.en:
Irene H. is a 24 year old, married, woman who has two children. She lives in an area called El Recreo that is two hours from Puerto de Veracruz. The people in her town primarily make a living by growing: rice, cucumber, watermelon, melon, and tomatoes. Doña Irene mostly sells woman’s clothing for a living, but she also sells plastic silverware. She makes most of her sales in her neighborhood to her friends and family. She buys her merchandise in another town and is asking for a loan to buy and transport her merchandise. Her goal is to eventually build a store in front of her house. In this way she could help her husband and provide her children with a better future. Doña Irene is the representative of the group called “Las Perlas” that is made up of four women. They sells soft drinks, shoes (by catalog), and cut hair. This is why they are asking for a loan of 1,500 to be able to invest in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara Ropa de Dama

loans.name: Concern Group

texts.en:
Sahid M. I. (left), age 35, is the leader of this group. Sahid was born in Magburaka town. He is single with two children who are still in primary school. Sahid owns a bar where he has been selling both soft and hard drinks for over five years now.

Sahid M. I., Septimus C. and Marie K. named their group "Concern". They are small scale business people based in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are receiving from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profit and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To invest in a bar

loans.name: Kick Poor United Group

texts.en:
Here are Issa L., Yeabu K. and Kadiatu K.. They named their group Kick Poor United. This is the fourth loan these entrepreneurs are receiving from SMT/Kiva. With previous loans, these entrepreneurs were able to expand their businesses, both in size and in quality. As a result, they experienced a vast improvement in sales, profit margin and in their standard of living. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are requesting a new loan in order to further strengthen their businesses.

Issa L. (middle) is the leader of the group. Issa was born in Magburaka town 42 years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have four children together. All of their children are still in primary schools. Issa sells cosmetics and ready-to-wear-clothes in Magburaka town. He has been a businessman for more than 10 years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Tamtamnehsu Group

texts.en:
Here are Mariatu C., Zainab Koroma, Fatmata C. and Mabinty K.. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They called their group the Tamtamnehsu group, a Temne phrase meaning "Think about Us." This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profits and consequently improve their standard of living.  

Mariatu C. (left) is the leader of Tamtamnehsu group. She is 29 and was born in Magburaka town. She is married with three children; two in primary school and one in nursery school. Mariatu has sold used clothes and onions for more than seven years now. With this loan, she will be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Las Tequileras Group

texts.en:
Las Teliqueras is a group of 12 women who are seeking their very first loan. The women have variety of businesses, including selling clothes, cosmetics and food. One woman has a bakery, another is a cook, and another runs a photocopier in a bookstore.

The members of the group plan to use the loan to provide capital for their businesses and to improve the quality of their goods. Half of the members of the group have previous experience borrowing money from institutions, while the other half of the group is borrowing money for the first time.		

The women sincerely hope that their businesses succeed and their incomes improve.

loans.use: Buying capital and improving quality of products

loans.name: Msf Group

texts.en:
Here are Alimany M., Mustapha S. and Amadu K. of the MSF group. They are businessmen in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each to help them develop their businesses.

Alimany M. (left) is the leader of this group. Alimany was born in Magburaka town 37 years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have four children. Three of their children are in primary school and the last is still being breastfed. Alimany sells tires and inner tubes. He also patches inner tubes in Magburaka town. He has been in this business for eight years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Good Luck Enterprise Group

texts.en:
Here are Yeabu Z. K., Adama K. and Yeabu G.. They are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. They named their group Good Luck Enterprise. This is not the first loan these women have accessed from SMT/Kiva. Previous loans have made significant impacts in the businesses and personal lives of these women. With the profit made out of their businesses, they were able to repay their loans on time and in full, feed their children, send them to school and pay medical bills. 

Yeabu Z. K. (right) is the leader of this group. She is now age forty-five, married to a businessman and they have six children. Some of their children are now in secondary schools and others are still in primary schools. Yeabu was born in Magburaka town where she has been selling traditional medicines for more than fifteen years now.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Tabatsufinu Group

texts.en:
Aminata C. (second from left) is the leader of this group. Aminata has been selling shoes, cigarettes, sardines, milk, corn beef, etc. for three years now. She is married to a police officer and they have three children together. Two of their children are in secondary school and one is in primary school. Aminata was born in Lunsar, in northern Sierra Leone, 32 years ago. 

Aminata C., Fatu K., Maliki S. and Marie T. call their group Tabatsufinu, a Temne phrase meaning "Be Kind to Us." They are business people based in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make better profit and consequently improve on their wellbeing.

loans.use: To invest in retail business

loans.name: Cerrito Group

texts.en:
The committee named Cerrito was formed on March 24th, 2008, thanks to the director of the group, Mrs. Antoliana Fernandez, who works as a saleswoman. She talked to a loan officer about forming a group and then gathered 18 women. The group works well together and is now on its fifth cycle with the Fundación. 

This is an excellent group thanks to the solidarity they have. Each woman invests her loan in her respective business. All of the women participate in other activities to save money as a group and to mutually help each other achieve goals they have as individuals and with the Fundación Paraguaya. The committee participates in weekly meetings and is extremely supportive. 

  1  Antoliana F. - Handicrafts sales 
  2  Cantalicia Q. - Avon cosmetics sales 
  3  Liduvina C. - Food sales 
  4  Felicita C. - General store 
  5  María Z. G. - Broom sales 
  6  Brígida S. - Food sales 
  7  Rumilda Vázquez - Clothing sales 
  8  Ladislaa P. - Lottery ticket sales 
  9  Sadi S. - Chicken sales 
10  Antonia S. - Fruit sales 
11  Josefa M. - Fruit and vegetable sales 
12  Analía Q. - Fruit sales 
13  Marisel E. - Food sales 
14  Adelaida G. - Dressmaker 
15  Fidelina O. - Diner 
16  Francisca Z. - Clothing and shoe sales 
17  Silvia M. - Beverage sales 
18  Idalina F. - Fruit sales

loans.use: To purchase materials for handicrafts

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace P. sells fresh and smoked fish in Torkor near Kpando. She has received junior high education. She is married and has twelve dependents. Her husband is a fisherman with a small fishing boat and an old net.

Grace has been selling fresh and smoked fish since 2000. She is responsible for all the needs of the twelve dependents. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke and sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to smoke and sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes K. sells fresh and smoked fish in Torkor near Kpando. Agnes has received junior high education. She is married and has ten dependents. Her husband is a fisherman who fishes with outmoded fishing equipment.

Agnes has been selling fresh and smoked fish since 2006. She is responsible for all the financial needs of her ten dependents. Her loan will be used to buy fresh fish from other fishermen to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish from other fishermen to sell

loans.name: Plan De Lucha 3 Group

texts.en:
Ramona is part of a solidarity group called Plan de Lucha, or Plan of Attack. The members of this group live in the small town of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic and are seeking a loan to build their businesses. This group has successfully completed four loan cycles and has enjoyed the opportunity these loans have provided them. They seek another loan to continue to build their businesses and provide for their families.

Ramona runs two businesses, one selling women´s undergarments and one selling milk. With this loan she would like to buy more of each to increase her inventory to meet the increasing demand in the community. Ramona lives with her husband Felipe and her three children aged 15, 7, and 6. All of her children attend school and, with this loan, she can grow her business to continue to be able to provide an education for her children.

Ramona and the entire Plan de Lucha group appreciate the opportunity that these micro-loans have given them and hope to continue in their success.

loans.use: To buy more women's underwear and milk for her businesses

loans.name: Kory Jaulitas Group

texts.es: La Asociación Comunal “ Kory Jaulitas” que significa “Jaula de Oro” es un grupo de señoras muy unidas y alegres, con aproximadamente 5 años de vida se encuentra en el Centro Focal “German Busch”, sus integrantes en su mayoría se comunican con el idioma aymará (idioma nativo), así también, la mayoría se dedica al tejido de diferentes prendas, puede ser a mano o a máquina, una de ellas es Reyna L. su especialidad es tejer ropa de bebe y en esta época de frío tiene mucha demanda. Todas las integrantes de Kory Jaulita manifiestan que el  crédito que están obteniendo les permitirá tener mayor movimiento económico y podrán comprar materia prima como la lana.
texts.en:
The “Kory Jaulitas” Communal Association, which means “Jaula de Oro (Cage of Gold)”, is a group of very united and happy women who have been meeting for approximately five years at the “German Busch” Center. The majority of the members communicate in the Aymará language (their native language), and the majority are in the business of knitting different garments, both by hand and machine. One of them is Reyna L. whose specialty is to knit baby clothes and in this season of cold weather she has a lot of demand. All of the members of Kory Jaulita indicate that the loans that they are receiving will allow them to have a better financial situation and they will be able to purchase premium material such as wool.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of premium material

loans.name: Kuña Kyre'y Group

texts.en:
This committee is named Kuña Kyre’y. It was formed on November 7th, 2008 thanks to the director of finances for the group, Mrs. Karina G. who works selling jewelry. After talking to a loan officer, she helped gather 19 women who work well together and are currently in their third loan with Fundación Paraguaya.

It’s a good and supportive group that continues working hard. They invest their loans in their respective businesses. They all participate in activities to raise funds as a group, and they mutually help each other achieve their common goals, both individually and as a group. They participate in weekly meetings and supportively work together. 

1. Silvia Carolina V. - - - Undergarment and Avon cosmetics sales
2. Norma G. - - - Dressmaker
3. Karina B. - - - Undergarment sales
4. Natalia G. - - - Jewelry sales
5. Feliciana L. - - - Dressmaker
6. Olga A. - - - Diner
7. Estanislaa A. - - - Clothing sales
8. Sandra M. - - - Undergarment sales
9. Jorgelina R. - - - Snack sales
10. Rosalina D. - - - Handicraft sales
11. Leticia S. - - - Fruit and vegetable sales
12. Evelin G. - - - Manicure and pedicure
13. Lorenza M. - - - Undergarment sales
14. Carolina Q. - - - Dressmaker
15. Ma. Cristina Ávalos - - - Food sales
16. Yolanda Ávalos - - - Fruit and vegetable sales
17. Karina G. - - - Jewelry sales
18. Verónica N. - - - Convenience store
19. Nélida R. - - - Dressmaker

loans.use: The purchase of merchandise for sale or of raw materials

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian D. is married and has 15 dependants. She has received schooling through junior high. Vivian sells smoked fish in Torkor near Kpando, which she has done since 2005. Her husband is a fisherman who earns little for an income. Vivian uses all her income in looking after the large family. Vivian will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vivian plans to reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh fish

loans.name: Las Luciernagas Group

texts.en:
Las Luciernagas is a group of twelve women who have businesses in a variety of industries. Maria bakes bread, Tereza sells clothes, Esneide designs and sells her own clothing, Gerardo rents out tables and living room furniture, Elena sells health supplements, Celina has a DJ service, Marlene cleans, and the rest of the women sell food.

Some of the women have a lot of experience in their businesses, like Esneide, who has been in the clothing business for 33 years. On the other hand, Gerardo, Elena and Maribel have only been in their business for one year each.

Eight of the members have taken out loans in the past and the rest of them are borrowing money for the first time. They are all looking forward to growing their businesses with their micro-loans.

loans.use: To buy products and improve the quality of their products

loans.name: San Martin Group

texts.en:
San Martin is a group of 12 women who are taking out their first loan. These women mainly sell food. One woman sells bread, another fast food, and a third cooks entire meals. Others make a living selling clothes and cosmetics.

Seven of the twelve women have previous experience taking out institutional loans, while the other are taking out their very first loans. All of them are looking forward to expanding their businesses with the food, cosmetic, and clothing products they will purchase with their loan.

loans.use: Buy inventory and improve quality of products

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras Group

texts.en:
The committee Mujeres Luchadoras was formed on Mary 22, 2009, thanks to the director of the group, Nilsa R., who works at selling vegetables. She approached a loan officer about starting a committee for women entrepreneurs. Nilsa was then able to gather a group of 16 women who work well together. 

The women use the credit given to them to invest in their respective businesses in order to mutually achieve common goals, both individually and as a group. The women participate in weekly meetings and show support and interest in each other’s activities. 

1	Nilsa R. - Vegetable sales 
2	Melissa D. - Food sales 
3	Marcelina M. - Small grocery store 
4	Daniela T. - Fruit sales 
5	Celestina G. - Food sales 
6	Jacinta D. - Food sales 
7	Matilde M. - Charcoal sales 
8	Gladys T. - Fruit sales 
9	María B. - Fruit and vegetable sales  
10	Sunilda M. - Vegetable sales 
11	Jorgelina O. - Small grocery store 
12	Celia F. - Avon cosmetics sales 
13	Librada P. - Vegetable sales 
14	Martina R. - Diner 
15	Mirian B. - Food sales 
16	Adolfina G. - Chipa (local bread) sales

loans.use: To purchase vegetables for sale

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.en:
Julio is 36 years old and lives with Juana, who is 31.  The couple has two children, 7 and 5 years old, who attend elementary school. 

Julio started working in construction with his father at a very young age, which he still does to this day.  Also, thanks to the effort and help of his wife, the couple has been able to start a small, well-stocked grocery store based out of their home.  The store has produced excellent economic results.  The store sells milk, which Julio and Juana obtain from from their four cows, which produce a substantial amount of milk.  

Julio is applying for this loan in order to purchase merchandise such as flour, rice, noodles, oil, etc., to better stock their small grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase flour, rice, noodles, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: Kantutas De Oro Group

texts.es: En el Centro Focal “German Busch”, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal “Kantutas de Oro” que tiene 16 integrantes,  cuenta con aproximadamente 5 años de vida, todas tienen diferentes negocios como: venta de fruta, elaboración de muebles, venta de comida, ferretería, venta de ropa, atención de llamadas y otros. Su presidenta es Juana T. quien indica que el grupo se formo con amigas y vecinas que viven cerca del Centro Focal, lo que les gusta de Pro Mujer  es el servicio de salud, porque  les atienden a ellas,a sus hijos, esposos y familiares, además les agrada mucho las capacitaciones que imparten en Destrezas en Negocios ya que les orienta a administrar mejor sus negocios.
texts.en:
In the “German Busch” Center we find the “Kantutas de Oro (Flowers of Gold)” Communal Association which has 16 members and has existed for approximately five years. All of the members have different businesses such as: the sale of fruit, the building of furniture, the sale of food, a hardware store, the sale of clothes, customer service, and others. Their president is Juana T. who indicates that the group is made up of friends and neighbors who live around the Center. What they like about Pro Mujer (Pro-Woman) is the health service because they attend to the women, their children, husbands, and relatives. Furthermore, they very much appreciate the abilities they are taught in Business Skills as it enables them to better administrate their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Fidel

texts.en:
Mr. Fidel G. is a professional photographer. He is 44 years old and married to Mrs. Milva Liz Figueredo, who is 34 years old. They have two children that study and live in the San Miguel neighborhood.

Fidel worked as a secretary to a photographer from a very young age. The photographer helped Fidel learn and understand the field and after several years he was able to start his own business. He started his photography business 22 years ago and through his work he has been able to pay for household expenses as well as the education of his daughters.

Fidel found out about the Fundación Paraguaya through a friend. He applied for a loan in order to inject more capital into his business, to change some elements of his job and to replace equipment that wasn’t working well anymore.

loans.use: To purchase lights, cables and flash

loans.name: Facundo

texts.en:
Facundo G. is 75 years old, married and has eight older children. He works making clay bricks that are later baked in a firewood oven. These bricks are then used as the raw material for building houses. Facundo began working with his father from whom he learned the trade. He currently has one of the most renowned brick-making businesses in the area. He produces about 40,000 to 45,000 bricks per month. His success is due to the weather resistant, high quality bricks he makes.

Thanks to his work and constant effort, he has been able to build his own house and with his income cover the expenses of his children’s educations as well as household expenses. The credit he has applied for is for the repair of a bricklaying mill, which is used to mix clay and other raw materials to make bricks.

loans.use: Repair of brick mill

loans.name: Plan De Lucha Group 2

texts.en:
Plan D. Lucha consists of a group of entrepreneurs in the small town of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic who are seeking a micro loan. The members of this group have successfully completed four loans and are eager to continue to grow their businesses with another loan.


Mercedez is the leader of this group and runs a fruit stand. With this loan, she would like to buy more bananas so she can make more guineo, a popular local dish of fried green bananas.


Mercedez lives with her husband and four children aged 20, 17, 15, and 14. She says that her family has been blessed with good health and she would like to grow her business in order to continue providing a healthy life for her children.


Mercedez is an inspiring example of the opportunities that micro loans give the members of this community.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: El Milagro Group 3

texts.en:
Sandra is part of a solidarity group called El Milagro, or The Miracle. This group lives in the small agricultural town of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic and has been together since 2006. This tight-knit group of friends has helped each other grow their businesses over the years and they are seeking another loan to further their success.

Sandra is the 37-year-old mother of two (aged 11 and 4) and owns her own salon. With this loan, she hopes to buy supplies such as shampoo and nail polish so that she can serve more customers. With the extra income, she hopes to save up so that she can send her children to the university and fulfill her dream of seeing them become successful professionals. 

Sandra and the whole El Milagro group appreciate the opportunities micro loans have given them and they hope to continue their success.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her salon

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen M. D. C. is 48 years old and married to Mr. Ramon C., 55. They have three older children. Carmen owns a small grocery store that is located in the city Union. It is a well-stocked store, attracting a large clientele.  She has a substantial income from this business as well as excellent references, both professional and personal. 

She has a project to expand her store to a mini supermarket that is well-stocked, as she already has many clients.  She would also like to her expand her business space.

loans.use: Capital for her business

loans.name: Marcos

texts.en:
Mr. Marcos G. B. is from the Republicano neighborhood of the city of San Estanislao. He is 35 years old and married to Mrs. Petrona Paredes, 34. They have four older children and own their own home.  

Marcos works making and selling tapioca, a traditional Paraguayan food, to a well-established clientele. It provides him a steady income. He has good references, both professional and personal, as he is a hardworking man. He would eventually like to be able to trade in his car for one with more capacity to carry his products.

loans.use: The purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Victorina

texts.en:
Mrs. Victorina A. is 49 years old and is married to Mr. Maximo Candia Portillo, who is 59 years old. They have six children.  They live in the city of San Estanislao in their own home. 

Victorina works renting chairs, tables and silverware to people hosting large parties and events.  She has many clients in the area, and in neighboring cities.  Through the services she offers, she is able to earn a substantial living.  She is applying for a loan to be able to expand her inventory in order to always have her tables, chairs and silverware in good condition.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Ignacio

texts.en:
Mr. Ignacio Martínez B. is from the city of Choré. He is 34 years old and is married to Mrs. Esmelda Villalba, who is 30 years old and owns her own house. Ignacio owns an auto body workshop, which has been running for seven years. He also owns a tire shop. Both are strategically located and Ignacio has a well-established clientele.

He would like to build a platform on which to put his spare parts and vehicles for sale. Ignacio is a hardworking man with great personal references.

loans.use: The purchase of crashed vehicles

loans.name: La Buena Fe, Group 10

texts.en:
Elena J. is 22 years old and lives in the medium-sized town of El Seybo, in the eastern part of the Dominican Republic. She is the group coordinator for La Buena Fe (The Good Faith) bank, Group 10 of Kiva and Esperanza International. Her story is typical of her fellow group members' experiences with Kiva and Esperanza.

Today, Elena is looking to take out her second Kiva loan to grow her clothing and food retail business. She currently sells clothing, bananas, habichuela (a staple Dominican bean dish) and vegetables, but she would like to diversify her merchandise to offer earrings as well. Although she has been running her own business for at least the past five years, Elena only became a client of Kiva and Esperanza six months ago, after her mother had success as a borrower of microloans. Since becoming a Kiva and Esperanza client, Elena reports that both her business and her life have changed significantly for the better. Elena has already been able to grow her business so that her second loan is twice the amount of her first. This additional access to capital is especially important to Elena because, although she has no dependents, she lives on her own and supports herself entirely through her independent retail outlet.

With her new loan, Elena hopes to expand her merchandise offerings and to have further success with her in-home business. She is pictured in the center of the photo with her fellow members of La Buena Fe bank, Group 10.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise to sell

loans.name: Gregorio Cristaldo

texts.en:
Mr. Gregorio Cristaldo R. is from the city of Choré.  He is 41 years old and is married to Mrs. Maria Magdalena Rodas de Cristaldo, who is 36 years old. They have three children.  They all live in their own home. 

Gregorio owns a small grocery store and butcher shop, which has been open for fifteen years.  He has 20 hectares of land where he raises cattle and grows corn and tapioca.  Gregorio’s dream is to buy a large truck to transport his products.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for sale

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
La señora Felicitas, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nueva Generación 2000”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 58 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene hijos mayores e independientes.  Ella tiene estudios de primaria completa, y vive en el Barrio Santa Bárbara.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 7 años,  su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual invirtió en su negocio de compra y venta de abarrotes. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 600.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio, comprará abarrotes como arroz, azúcar, leche, harina, fideos, etc.

Su mayor deseo es seguir trabajando.

A ella le gusta la forma de trabajo y las facilidades de pago que les da Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Felicitas belongs to the communal bank “Nueva Generación 2000”, which is located in the district of Llave, the province of El Collao, and in the the department of Puno. She is 58 years old, married, and has children that are independent and out of the house. She lives in the neighborhood Santa Bárbara. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for the past 7 years. Her first loan was for $100 (300.00 Soles), which she invested in her business of buying and selling groceries. At this moment she needs a loan of $200 (600.00 Soles) to invest in her business. She will use the money to buy grocery items like rice, sugar, milk, pasta, flour, etc. Felicitas' greatest wish is to continue working. She likes the way the organization Manuela Ramos is run and how they make making payments easy.

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items to sell like rice, sugar, milk, pasta, flour, etc.

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es: Doña Gloria Maria Gutiérrez, reside en el barrio Hialeah en la capital de Managua, tiene 47 años de edad, con un hijo mayor de edad, es viuda. Su negocio es un cafetín que desde hace seis años administra, el cual inicio con apoyo de su esposo sus planes es poder ofertar en mayores cantidad de productos y variedades  a sus clientes. Con este crédito es su cuarto ciclo el cual va invertir en la compra de materiales para construir pantry y remodelar la cocina. Da las gracias a la institución por los beneficios de crecer en el negocio como en las mejoras logradas hasta ahora.
texts.en:
Ms. Gloria Maria Gutiérrez lives in the Hialeah neighborhood of the capital city of Managua. She is a 47-year-old widow with a grown-up son. She has owned a snack bar for 6 years, setting it up with the support of her husband. She plans to be able to offer a greater amount and variety of products to her patrons. She is in her fourth loan cycle, and she will invest the loan in purchasing construction materials to build a pantry and remodel the kitchen. She gives thanks to the institute for helping her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a pantry and remodel the kitchen

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.es:
La señora Eusebia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Calceteras”  que esta ubicado en el distrito D. Juliaca, Provincia D. San Román, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 55 años D. edad, D. estado civil casada y es madre D. 05 hijos.  Tiene estudios primaria incompleta (2do año),  vive en el  Barrio Santa Rosa.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 01 año,  su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para la compra D. plásticos para incrementar su negocio. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para comprar productos D. plásticos, bolsas, etc. para su negocio.

Su mayor sueño es seguir trabajando y surtir mejor su negocio.
texts.en:
Eusebia belongs to the communal bank “Las Calceteras” which is located in the district of Juliaca, in the province of San Román, and in the department of Puno. She is 55 years old, is married and the mother of 5 children. She studied in school until about 2nd graD. and she lives in the neighborhood of Santa Rosa. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for the past year. Her first loan was for $100 (300 Soles), which she used to to purchase plastic products to increase her business. At this time she is requesting a loan for $175 (500 Soles) to buy plastic products, bags, etc. for her business. Her greatest wish is to continue working and to stock her business with more items.

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic products, bags, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen tiene 43 años, es una persona muy querida por sus vecinos debido a su buen carácter. Es viuda y tiene 4 hijos que viven cómodamente en su casa propia. Ella es propietaria de varios terrenos cultivables; donde siembra (con la ayuda de sus hijos y peones) plátanos, piñas y mayormente café. Además, cada semana también se dedica a la compra y venta de frutas, para ello se traslada las chacras donde tiene a más de 20 agricultores que la abastecen de diversas frutas a precios muy cómodos, de ese modo ella revende a precios accesibles a sus compañeras de comercio ambulante. Desde entonces ha ganado mucha clientela, sus compradores la conocen como “Camicha” y ella es muy feliz con su negocio, pues se siente una madre muy útil que puede financiar la educación de sus hijos, con miras de que logren ser profesionales. Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, demostrando puntualidad en cada una de sus cuotas y en su cargo como tesorera de su banco comunal. Carmen tiene un trato muy amable para realizar las cobranzas a los integrantes de su grupo, pero de incumplir alguno de ellos los anima a ser responsables con palabras muy serias, las cuales escuchan todos atentamente. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá para incrementar la cantidad de frutas que vende.
texts.en:
Carmen is 43 years old and is is very loved by her neighbors because of her good character. She is a widow and has four children who live comfortably in her own house. She is the owner of several cultivable fields where she plants (with the help of her children and laborers) bananas, pineapples, and mostly coffee. In addition, each week she works buying and selling fruit. For that she goes to the farms where she has more than 20 farmers who supply her with various fruits at very good prices. In this way she is able to resell at prices accessible to her street vendor companions. Over time she has earned many clients. Her customers know her as Camicha and she is very happy with her business since she feels she is a useful mother who can finance the education of her children, with hopes they can achieve their goal of becoming professionals. This is her fifth credit with MFP, demonstrating punctuality with each of her repayments. In her position as treasurer of the communal bank Carmen has a very friendly way of carrying out collections from the members of her group but if any of them do not make their payments she encourages them to be responsible with very serious words, which they listen to carefully. The money she requests will be invested to increase the quantity of fruits she sells.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the inventory of merchandise

loans.name: Jesús

texts.es: Jesús tiene 40 años, es un hombre responsable que trabaja muy duro, hace 15 años vive con su pareja y madre de sus 5 hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 22 años se dedica al cultivo de plátanos, café y frutos cítricos, pero lo que más le agrada es el café, por serle más rentable; aunque demora de 2 a 3 años y requiere de mucha inversión hasta lograr que fructifique de manera uniforme para recién iniciar la recolección. Cada vez que su chacra de café está a punto de cosechar se llena de regocijo, puesto que es el momento de acumular ganancias con las que cubre los gastos de comestibles y prendas de vestir para todos sus hijos. Jesús también trabaja en otras chacras como jornalero y muchos de sus vecinos prefieren darle el trabajo a él, por ser muy eficiente, dejando los terrenos muy limpios, por lo que le pagan entre 15 a 17 soles diarios; y esto es de mucha valía en su economía durante el tiempo que no tiene cosechas. Mediante su trabajo, Jesús espera adquirir otros terrenos cultivables en aras de mejorar su calidad de vida. Este es su 5to crédito con MFP, durante los cuatro ciclos anteriores ha demostrado cumplir puntualmente cada uno de sus pagos. En su banco comunal no tiene ningún cargo, pero algunas veces se encarga de pasar los comunicados de su asesor de crédito al resto de los integrantes. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de 10 sacos de fertilizantes para sus cultivos de café.
texts.en:
Jesus is 40 years old. He is a responsible, hard-working man. For fifteen years he has lived with his partner and the mother of his five children in their own house. For 22 years he has been growing bananas and citrus fruit, but what he prefers to grow is coffee, as it is more profitable, even though it takes 2 to 3 years to mature and requires a lot of effort to ensure that it grows uniformly, in order to start harvesting it. Every time his coffee crop is ready to be harvested he is very happy because this is the time to earn money, which covers food and clothing expenses for all his children. Jesus also works on other farms as a day laborer, and many of his neighbors prefer to give him work because he is very efficient, leaving the fields very clean. For this reason they pay him between 15 and 17 soles a day. This is very valuable to him at the times when he has nothing to harvest. Through his work, Jesus hopes to acquire additional arable land in order to improve his quality of life. This is his fifth loan from MFP. During the four previous cycles he has made his payments on time. He does not have a position in his communal bank, but sometimes he is responsible for passing messages from the lender on to the other members. The money he is requesting will be used to purchase 10 bags of fertilizer for his coffee plants.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es: Maribel tiene 53 años, es una mujer muy abnegada y trabajadora, está separada de su pareja y vive con 3 de sus 7 hijos. Por más de 15 años viene elaborando y vendiendo tamales (plato típico), cuando sus hijos están libres el más pequeño es el encargado de moler el maíz, ella amasa y sus otros hijos, en competencia, envuelven el tamal con hoja de plátano. Para darse abasto, anteriormente Maribel se levantaba a las 2 de la madrugada, ya que prepara entre 400 y 500 tamales para que a las 8 de la mañana los distribuya a sus compradores al por mayor. A base de este trabajo pudo educar y alimentar a todos sus hijos, es por eso que se siente satisfecha con el mismo, pero debido al esfuerzo empezó a sentir dolores musculares, por lo que ahora sólo prepara por las tardes 300 tamales. Una de las dificultades de Maribel es que su hija mayor se fue con su pareja y dejó de pagar un préstamo, que ella ha asumido. Entonces, una vez que termine de pagar esa deuda, su deseo es de renovar su máquina de moler granos, ya que la que tiene actualmente ya no agiliza su trabajo. Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, durante los ciclos pasados demostró responsabilidad en cada uno de sus pagos y para este nuevo crédito reitera su compromiso. A su banco comunal le tiene mucha estima, ya que la apoyó con créditos que le han permitido seguir trabajando. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra de maíz y otros ingredientes para seguir preparando sus tamales.
texts.en:
Maribel is 53 years old. She is a very selfless and hard-working woman. She is separated from her partner and lives with 3 of her 7 children. For more than 15 years she has been making and selling tamales (a traditional dish). When her children are available, the youngest is in charge of grinding the corn, she kneads the dough, and her other children wrap the tamales in banana leaves. To handle all of this work, Maribel used to get up at 2:00am in order to prepare 400 to 500 tamales and distribute them to her wholesale buyers at 8:00am. With this work she was able to feed and educate all of her children, so she was very happy with it, but due to all of the effort, she began to experience muscle pains, and now she only prepares 300 tamales in the afternoons. One of Maribel's difficulties is that her oldest daughter left with her partner and failed to repay a debt, which Maribel has assumed. Once this debt has been repaid, she wants to update her corn grinder, as the one she currently uses does not help her to speed up her work. This is Maribel's fifth loan with MFP. During past cycle she has demonstrated responsibilty in making each of her payments, and for this new loan, she reiterates her commitment. Maribel has great appreciation for her communal bank, which has supported her with loans that have permitted her to continue working. The money she is currently requesting will be used to purchase corn and other ingredients to prepare her tamales.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make tamales

loans.name: Elci

texts.es:
La señora Elci, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Estrellitas D. Jorge Chávez II”, Distrito D. Tarapoto, Provincia D. San Martín, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 54 años, 02 hijos, que aun dependen D. ella.

Deseando ver profesionales a sus hijos, y tener sus propios ingresos para poder lograrlo, decidió emprender su propio negocio. Nos cuenta que en su vida paso por diferentes dificultades, su espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas D. salir adelante sola le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio D. preparación y venta D. bebidas como: chichas D. maíz y chichas D. jora y como complemento también venD. sus gaseosas.
Elci venD. sus bebidas en su misma casa y también sale por las calles a ofrecer sus bebidas y poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes que la mayoría son sus vecinos, chóferes, transeúntes D. la ciudad  y amigos, tiene mucha acogida y sus ventas le van muy bien, en las mañanas y en las tardes.

Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando insumos para sus preparar sus bebidas como: 2 kilos D. maíz y azúcar, que los compra a diario, ingredientes para dar sabor a sus bebidas como: clavo D. olor, canela, piñas, hielos. Parte del dinero lo invertirá también en la compra D. leña. Y paquetes D. gaseosa D. diferentes tamaños y sabores. 

Elci,  se siente con muchas fuerzas para seguir con sus ventas D. bebidas, sueña con  implementar mas su negocio con un Restaurant bien acondicionado para brindar a sus clientes un mejor servicio y atención. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento D. sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Elci is a member of the Las Estrellitas D. Jorge Chávez II communal bank, Tarapoto District, San Martin Province, San Martin Department. She is 54 years old and married, with two dependent children. Wishing to see her children become professionals, and have their own money in order to achieve this, she decided to start her own business. She tells us that she has faced many difficulties in her life, but her characteristic fighting spirit and her desire to get ahead compelled her to start her business preparing and selling beverages, such as different kinds of chicha (traditional Peruvian corn drinks), as well as sodas. Elci sells these drinks in her own home, and also goes into the streets to sell them. Little by little she became well-known among her customers, who incluD. her neighbors, drivers, visitors to the city and friends. She has been well-received and her sales are going well, both in the morning and in the afternoons. With this loan of 1,000 soles, she plans to purchase ingredients for her drinks, including 2 kilos of corn and sugar, which she buys daily. She will also purchase other ingredients to add to her drinks, including cloves, cinnamon, pineapple and ice, as well as firewood and sodas in different sizes and flavors. Elci is dedicated to continuing her beverage sales, but dreams of opening a well-equipped restaurant in order to give her customers better service and attention. She appreciates the Manuela Ramos movement for helping her achieve her goals and dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her beverages

loans.name: Angelica Ysolina

texts.es:
La señora Angélica Ysolina V. P. tiene 51 años, vive en el distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Superior Completa, tiene 2 hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Angélica se dedica a la confección y venta de vestidos de baile (marinera), también vende comida rápida como salchipollo en las noches.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Mujeres al Progreso, lo invirtió en la compra de telas, blondas y cintas para elaborar los vestidos de marinera.
El crédito de 1200 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de un carrito sanguchero usado, una vitrina  y sillas para su negocio.
Angélica  tiene como sueño tener su fuente de soda y una tienda donde venda los vestidos de marinera  y crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Angélica Ysolina V. P., 51, lives in the Porvenir district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She has a high school degree. She has two dependent children. She makes and sells dance dresses (Andean folk dance). She also sells fast food like “salchipollo” (a typical Peruvian dish) at night. With her first loan of 300 PEN, which she received from her Mujeres al Progreso Community Bank, she bought fabric, silk lace, and ribbons to make the folk dance dresses. She will use the loan of 1,200 PEN to buy a used sandwich cart, a display case, and chairs for her business. Angélica’s dreams are to have a soda fountain and a store where she sells her folk dance dresses and to grow as a small businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a used sandwich cart, a display case, and chairs for her business

loans.name: Magali Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Magali, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Estrellitas de Jorge Chávez II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 33 años, 03 hijos, que aun están a su cargo y es la razón por la cual, trabaja muy duro día a día.

Su espíritu  alegre y su anhelo de sacar adelante  a sus hijos, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes con cuyas ganancias ayudaría al ingreso económico de su familia, desde sus  inicios a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes. En la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega a comprar porque en ella  tiene todo los productos  que el ama de casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, desea invertirlo comprando arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Magali del Rosario, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, y perseverando día a día y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Mrs. Magali is a member of the communal bank “Las Estrellitas de Jorge Chávez II.” She lives with her partner, is 33 years old, and has three children who are her reason for working so hard each day. She is a happy person who longs to help her children get ahead in life. They are what motivated her to start her own business selling groceries, whose earnings will help her family out economically. She has had clients since she started and today has loyal clients who come to her store to buy from her each day because she sells the products that housewives need. She serves them personally with her habitual charm. With a loan of 1,500 soles, she would like to buy sacks of rice and sugar, packets of spaghetti, milk, various types of fish, eggs, and products for personal hygiene so she can continue to serve her clients well. Magali del Rosario feels strong about continuing to work is thankful for Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her have opportunities to develop themselves in businesses they are interested in.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara abarrotes, para aumentar sus productos

loans.name: Betilde Ivone

texts.es: La señora Betilde, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Tiempo es Oro”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 23 años de edad, 02 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella y está estudiando.Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio de Arreglo y Venta de Relojes, ubicada en un local alquilado frente a la plaza de la ciudad, posteriormente poco a poco fue aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad, haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  En la actualidad tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su relojeria a comprar relojes o para que les brinde el servicio de arreglo, es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con alegría y entusiasmo. Con el préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, invertirá comprando mas relojes en diferentes modelos, tanto para damas, caballeros y niños; correas, pilas de reloj. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá en la compra de lentes, que agregara a sus productos y así continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Betilde, anhela implementar mas su relojería y manifiesta que lo va a hacer realidad  porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo logra.   Agradece el apoyo que viene recibiendo  para emprender su propio negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Betilde is a member of the communal bank “El Tiempo es Oro.” She lives with her partner, is 23 years old, and has two children, one of whom is a student. Her enterprising character and love for her family motivated her to start her own business of fixing and selling watches. She rents a space in front of the city plaza. Bit by bit she has been gaining experience in watch repair and sale and has become well known and loved by her clients. Nowadays she has loyal clients who come daily to buy watches or have them fixed. She takes care of them personally (happily and enthusiastically). With this loan of 1,000 soles, she will buy more watches in different styles for men, women, and children. She will also buy watchbands and batteries. Some of the money will be invest in buying eyeglasses that she will add to her products and continue providing better and better service to her clients. Betilde longs to have her own watch shop and she will because she is woman who gets what she wants. She is grateful for the support she gets to help her have her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprara relojes para aumentar su stock

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es: Mercedes tiene 42 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos; Joseph de 13, Juliano de 10 y  Catherine de 4 años. Heredó de su padre varios terrenos cultivables y desde que se casó trabaja con su esposo sembrado papas, arvejas y maíz.  Pero lo que más le agrada son las arvejas por ser de menor inversión y la tierra rinde para tres cosechas, por ello cuida de sus planta diariamente para detectar el acecho de los mosquitos u otras plagas. Si es así, fumiga las hojas hasta que afloren y logren fructificar de manera uniforme para luego proceder a la recolección. A Mercedes le gusta trabajar en la chacra, a la que estima mucho por brindarle sus buenos frutos, que gracias a ellos pudo construir su casa y ahora está dedicada a los acabados para lograr vivir cómodamente con sus hijos. Este es su décimo crédito con MFP, en los préstamos anteriores demostró puntualidad en cada una de sus cuotas. Además, durante los últimos 5 ciclos consecutivos viene siendo la tesorera de su banco comunal y como es muy eficiente en su cargo, sus compañeros la animan a que continúe el siguiente ciclo. Con el dinero solicitado comprará una bolsa de semilla de arveja del tipo utrillo, por ser sus frutos de mejor tamaño.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 42 years old, married, and has three children: Joseph who is 13, Juliano who is 10, and Catherine who is 4 years old. She inherited several plots of land from her father and since she married, has worked with her husband growing potatoes, peas, and corn. She likes the peas best because they take the least work and provide enough for three harvests. She takes care of her plants each day looking for evidence of mosquitoes or other pests. If she finds pests, she fumigates the leaves until they have grown and flowered in a uniform way so she can then relocate them. Mercedes likes to work on her plot of land and is proud of it for producing well. Thanks to its production, they have been able to build a house and are now putting on the final additions so they can live comfortably with their children. This is her tenth loan with MFP. She has proven herself punctual with her payments on her former loans. In addition, she has been the treasurer for her communal bank for the past five cycles.
