She believes that having enough capital will enable her to further improve her general store business and to maintain its stability.  

Maribel lives in Barangay Binarzang in Quirino, Isabela together with her family. She is married to Chito and he works as an Overseas Filipino Worker. They are blessed with only one son, named John Michael.  Maribel hopes that by the time her child enters school they will already have saved for his education through college level. As parents, they always wanted to give the best for their son.

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Serapio

texts.en:
Serapio, who is now a widower, is engaged in a hog-raising business. He is requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000 for the maintenance of his business. He is 53 years old and lives with his adopted son in the peaceful village of Binarzang, Quirino, Isabela. 

Serapio claims that his adopted child is his main source of inspiration to work harder and become progressive in his business since his three children already have their own families and live separately and far from him.

According to Serapio, his previous loan has been of big help, not only in maintaining his hog-raising business, but also in providing for their daily needs and the allowances of his adopted son. Serapio hopes that his business will survive and continuously be maintained so that he is able to have a sustainable source of income.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is the simple mother of two. She believes that to be able to succeed in life she must try and try until she achieves what she dreamed of. She is married to Nolie, a farmer and they are blessed with two children: Nolie, 4 years old and Noliesa, 3 years old. Her family is happily living in the rural area of Barangay Binarzang Quirino, Isabela. 

Flordeliza operates a general store business that became her family’s alternative source of income to support their daily needs. She is borrowing an additional loan amounting to PHP 6,000 for the continuous improvement of her store.

Flordeliza wants to save more income for the future education of her children and also to assist her husband with their farming needs. She believes that God will help her provide what they need, and, hopefully, she will be able to make a way to elevate their standard of living through Kiva’s assistance and her hard work.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine believes that God had made His own way to provide what her family needs. She is very thankful for all the blessings she has received and, with that, she also shares her blessings with others in simple ways.  Josephine and her husband Edwin have three children; two of them are attending school.  Their youngest is just two years old and Josephine is also preparing for his future education as she also believes in the saying that “time is gold”.

Josephine believes that, with the help of Kiva lenders, her hog raising business will become more progressive. She is again requesting financial support to further sustain the growth of her business. She wanted to borrow at least PHP 4,000.00.  This amount will play a big part in enhancing her hog raising enterprise.  She hopes and prays that lenders will continuously support small entrepreneurs like her to be free and alleviated from poverty.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero L. is 48 years old and she is married with 6 children. She sells cooked foods. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Folly

texts.fr: Folly E. est un commerçant de friperies très dévoué. Agé de 35 ans, il est marié et père 2 enfants. Folly exerce ce commerce depuis 4 ans. Il souhaite avec ce crédit accroître la taille de son activité en payant des nouveaux produits de marque lui permettant de mieux répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle. Il compte sur cette chance pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Folly E. is a very dedicated second-hand clothing retailer. He is 35 years old, married and the father of two children. Folly has been in this business for 4 years. He hopes to expand his business with this loan by buying new brand-name products that will allow him to better respond to customer needs. He is counting on this chance to improve his family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new products for resale

loans.name: Bahari Group

texts.en:
Veronica M., 32, is married with four children, ages 14, 12,  9  and 7. She also is staying with her mother and father.  She has a business selling concrete at a place called Bahari beach, some few kilometers from the city center. She started this business about three years ago.  She works from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $75.

This will be Veronica’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to grow her business, paid hospital bills for her parents and has paid back her loan successfully.  She wants to use the new loan to buy a fridge to start selling juice, cold water and ice cream at the place where she sells the concrete.

Veronica will share this loan with her group Bahari, which totals 17 members. The members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Veronica is in the middle of the front row in green.

loans.use: To buy a fridge and start selling cold water, ice cream and juice

loans.name: Radhika

texts.en:
Mrs. Radhika B. is a tailor in the village of Bhakepati in Kathmandu district. She opened her tailoring shop 5 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like Kurta Sulwar, Blouse, Ladies long dress, Makhshi, and others.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. B. took a 6 month training course in tailoring near her town. Her husband died a few years ago and now she has sole responsibility for her daughter.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 20,000.00 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. Her economic condition is very low to fulfil the basic needs for her family, so she needs a loan to expand her business to earn more profit to fulfil her family's basic needs.

She lives with her father-in-law, mother-in-law and one daughter. Her father-in-law is a farmer and her daughter is studying in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Batduger

texts.en:
Batduger U. is 41 years old, married, and the father of three, aged 4 - 11. His family lives in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land he owns (residents own their land for free in Mongolia) in Uvurhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. Two of his children are attending a local elementary school and the youngest son is attending a local kindergarten.

Batduger is a professional welder. In 2006, he started running a small business making iron doors, fences and stoves. His spouse, Shinehuu, helps his business. Batduger requests a loan to purchase raw material and to build a work place on his land next to his ger. His says: "I really want to have a small house for my family’s needs. I'll keep working hard to have it." Thanks to his friendly and hardworking personality, he should succeed.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and to build a work place

loans.name: Sushila

texts.en:
Mrs. Sushila B. is a tailor in the town of Bhatkepati in Kathmandu. She opened her tailoring shop four years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like kurta salwar, blouses, ladies’ long dresses, makhshi and others. Before starting her own business, Mrs. B. took a six month training course in tailoring.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 15,000 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and spend on her son’s education.

Her husband's name is Rustam B. and he works in a private office. She has one son who is now in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for tailoring

loans.name: Sarita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarita B. is a tailor in the town of Bhatkepati. Tailoring is their traditional work so they learn tailoring work from their forefathers. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies’ long dresses, Makhshi, and others. She plans to use the loan of Rs 20,000 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her daughter's education.

Mrs. B. lives in a single family home with her husband and one daughter. Her husband helps her in her tailoring work and her daughter is studying in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma S. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 55 years old, married, and has one adult child. Thelma owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling peanuts in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2006, Thelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy M. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 36 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. Mercy owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Mercy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Mila

texts.en: Mila R. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 39 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Mila owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2000, Mila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Mila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her 16th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en:
Dolgorsuren B. is a open-minded and friendly person. She is married and the mother of two children aged 4 and 5 respectively. Both her children are attending a local kindergarten.

Two years ago her family moved from the countryside to the Province’s center to improve her family’s living conditions. As soon as she moved in, she bought an old boxcar and then maintained it as a small café. Since she is a very good chef, she has many repeat clients, mostly local residents. With the profits, she has been saving small amounts to expand her café and to hire one employee as a waitress. With this loan she will buy construction materials to expand her business place.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to expand her business place

loans.name: Marry Ann

texts.en: Marry Ann A. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 32 years old, married, and has four infant children. Marry Ann owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2001, Marry Ann joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Marry Ann is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 12th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Gina Helen

texts.en: Gina Helen E. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 41 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Gina Helen owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Gina Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. Gina Helen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Babughirana B Munyampogha Peluce Group

texts.en:
M. Peluce is a hardworking, active business lady aged 34. She is the single mother of one child who is going to school. She is also taking care of one dependent.

She has been dealing with tomatoes so far for one year. She is using the loan to purchase tomatoes in bigger volume which will improve her business. She is a courageous lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes in bigger volume to improve her business

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita M. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 48 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. Merlita owns and operates a service-based business providing general equipment rental to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2000, Merlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 15th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida P. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 50 years old, married, and has five adult children. Aida owns and operates a business running a food stall, selling a variety of food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Aida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Aida is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 12th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Takku Liggey 7 Teffes Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Takku Liggey 7 Teffes regroupe des femmes habitant un quartier en bordure de mer dans la ville côtière de Mbour située à 70 km de Dakar la capitale Sénégalaise. Elles s’activent dans des activités telles que la vente de chaussures, de tissus, de la restauration et de la pêche. Les revenus tirés de leurs différentes activités leur permettent d’entretenir leurs enfants. Avec le prêt qu’ils sollicitent ils veulent renforcer leur activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The Takku Liggey 7 Teffes Group brings together women who live by the sea in the coastal city of Mbour, located 70 km from the Senegalese capital Dakar. They work in activities like shoe sales, fabric sales, catering and selling fish. The incomes they generate from their different businesses allow them to support their children. They hope to strengthen their businesses with this loan.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen their businesses

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
M. Marie Chantal is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in the Kicukiro district of Kigali City, the capital of Rwanda. She and her husband have five children of the following ages: 13, 11, 9, 7, 5 years old.

Chantal operates her business in Kabeza sector where she owns a stall where she sells paints and hardware supplies. She has a great deal of experience from nine years in this business and she has a monthly profit of $165. She starts her daily business at 6:00 a.m. and finishes at 8:00 p.m. She has three regular workers.

Her first loan was 521,075 RWF. Now she is seeking her second loan worth 600,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company. With this loan she will buy more products for her hardware stall and she will reinvest the increased profit in the same business.

loans.use: To buy more hardware supplies

loans.name: Munhdalay

texts.en:
Munhdalay E. is a 30-year-old married man who has two children. His eldest child is a daughter who attends a local elementary school and the youngest is a son who is just 2 years old and stays at home. His family lives in "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land he has taken as a heritage from his father in Uvurhangay province. Uvurhangay is one of the Mongolian central provinces and is 400 kilometers from the capital city.

Since 2008, Munhdalay has been running a small café at the local market. The café income is his household's only income. To increase his daily income, he is planning to expand his café as soon as possible. Most of his clients are salesmen and saleswomen who work at the market stalls. His hope is to run his business successfully, then, with the profit, to built a house for his family needs. Munhdalay requests a loan to purchase a refrigerator for his business.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for his café

loans.name: Salinah Chebet

texts.en: Salinah is married to Samuel Sitienei and they have three children. She runs a retail shop in Olare in Eldoret town. Salinah has serviced one loan from KADET and, with this new loan, she intends to buy two bags of sugar, four gallons of cooking fat and two bags of rice. She has been in her retail business for four years and hopes to provide more variety for her increasing clientele. In future, Salinah intends to buy a commercial plot, educate her children, and expand her retail shop to a wholesale shop. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of sugar, rice, flour, cooking fat and othe household items

loans.name: Good Hope Masika Josephine Group

texts.en:
M. Josephine is married with six children, all going to school. And she also looks after five dependants who are also going to school.

She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as soap, sugar, salt, biscuits, sweets, etc. to meet her customers' demands and to expand her business. M. Josephine is a hardworking business woman whose dream remains expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as soap, sugar, salt, biscuits, sweets, etc and expand her business.

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui L. is a 35 year old married woman who is the mother of two daughters aged 10 and 15. Both her daughters are attending a local elementary school. Her family lives in Uvurhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces.

In 2005, she started running a retail business selling food products at the local market. She has been renting a stall and purchases a variety of food products such as bread, cookies and candies from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. Nergui goes to Ulaanbaatar once or twice in every month for her business since food product purchase is cheap and UB city is located 450 kilometres away from the Uvurhangay province.

Her husband Choidorj is a constructor. Choidorj helps his spouse by going to UB city to purchase food products sometimes, when he has time. Nergui's eldest daughter Maidarsuren, 15, also helps her mother's business. Nergui requests a loan to purchase more food products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy food products for her business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce A. is currently in the business of selling onions and paste and is requesting a loan to purchase more onions to sell. Joyce is 48 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has 7 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land and open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more onions to sell

loans.name: Good Hope Katusabe Beatrice Group

texts.en: K. Beatrice is twenty-five years old and married. She has a retail shop which she has been operating for three years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, boxes of matches, etc. She is adding stock to her business and she believes in serving her community fairly. She is a hard-working business lady whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, boxes of matches, etc.

loans.name: Melenikan

texts.en: Mama, as she is called, sells provisions and foodstuffs and has been in this business for eight years. Mama is 55 years old and married with  five children. She is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more more provisions and foodstuffs to sell in order to meet her customers' need. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Adjéoda

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce dans la menuiserie, il a ouvert son atelier en 2004, outre les commandes qu’il reçoit de ses clients, il fabrique lui-même des meubles et des lits qu’il expose pour attirer le regard des passants. Il exerce son activité à proximité d’un carrefour. Son stock de planches et des matières nécessaires à son activité étant épuisé, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des Bois grumes, 10 planches et divers autres matériaux.
Etant marié et père d’un enfant, c’est avec le revenu de son activité qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman works as a carpenter and opened his workshop in 2004. Apart from the orders he receives from customers, he makes and displays his own furniture and beds to catch the attention of passers-by. His business is located by an intersection.
Given that he is out of wooden planks and materials necessary for his work, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase wooden logs, 10 wooden planks and various other materials.
Married and the father of one child, he provides for his family with his business revenue.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood, wooden planks and accessories

loans.name: Kilimanjaro Group

texts.en:
Fadhili M., age 53, is married with five children, ages 29, 26, 21,17 and 13.  He has had a genge duka (kiswahili fruits and vegetables) business for seven years.  He works daily from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.  He is able to earn a monthly profit of about $230.

This will be Fadhili’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants a loan to increase the stock of his business.  

Fadhili will share this loan with his group  Kilimanjaro, which totals 15 members. These members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Fadhili is second from left, front row.

loans.use: To grow his business by buying more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Greetings from N. Jane, a 31-year-old married woman with 3 children aged 8, 5, 2 years old. She lives in Nyarugenge district in Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur has a stall selling paint in Kimironko sector; she is requesting her first loan of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company, the partner of World Vision Rwanda.

Jane has an experience of 7 years and employs one person in the business. Before getting the loan, Jane earned a monthly profit of $95 US and she hopes to have much profit after getting the loan because she will satisfy the needs of her customers. With the expected loan, this entrepreneur will buy more products and with the increased profit she will continue to expand the business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Odiwo

texts.en: F. is 33 years old, a widow, and has two children. She has been in business for the past seven years after two years' training. She is requesting the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa V. is a rice grower. She is 30 years old, the mother of three children. She has been tilling a 1.1 hectare farm. The harvest that she gets from her farm goes to buy their household needs as well as paying tuition and other school fees. She dreams of having an abundant harvest. She needs additional capital to realize that dream.

Vanessa is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and other farming needs.

She is now happy receiving the credit assistance for her business as well as training and insurance coverage services from CEVI.

loans.use: fertilizer and other farming necessities

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn P. says, "It is really difficult having a farm business but no capital to run it. My husband and I are tilling a 1.25 hectare farm. We really need additional capital to sustain our livelihood and grow our business."  Merlyn is a 32-year-old farmer with two children. She is asking a loan of PHP 15,000. This will help the family save the business. She thinks that by buying the needed fertilizers and insecticides, she will be able to increase the yield. 

CEVI is reaching out to more people to start a business. CEVI provides credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: Fertilizers, insecticides, and other farming necessities

loans.name: Obasoro

texts.en: G. is a widow. She is 42 years old and has four children. She sells underwear for ladies and children and has been in this trade for four years. She has been borrowing from LAPO for three years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more underwear to sell.

loans.use: To purchase underwear to sell

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto E. is a rice farmer from Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur, a poor community in Mindanao. His livelihood is farming rice and raising ducks. He is tilling a 1-hectare farm. He is the father of four children, and he works very hard to support his family’s daily needs. Now, he would like to improve the size of his harvest. He is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and to fulfill other farming needs. The loan will really help him achieve better yields. 

CEVI helps small farmers sustain their livelihood. CEVI provides clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: Farming necessities

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie G. is managing a small parcel land that is used as a rice farm. She is 39 years old and has three children. Her ultimate goal in life is to send all her children to school. She is doing her best to support the needs of her family.

She wants to apply for a loan of PHP 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farming necessities that will improve her harvest. If she improves the harvest she will earn a lot of money and be able to easily buy the things her family needs. 

The program that CEVI offers has helped many farmers sustain their livelihoods. CEVI provides not just loans, but also training and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: Farming necessities

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: Christian A. is a fisherman in Torkor, which is a fishing community near Kpando. Christian has a junior high education.  He is married and has 12 dependants. His wife is a trader whose income is too small to support him in taking care of the large family. Christian has been a fisherman since 2004. He is responsible for all the financial needs of the family. His loan will be used to buy fishing accessories such as a net and a bigger boat. He hopes to reinvest the new profit back in his business.

loans.use: Fishing accessories

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans N. T. is a fisherman in Torkor at Kpando. Evans N. has received a junior high education.  He is married and has 10 dependants. His wife is a fishmonger who depends on her husband's catch. He is solely responsible for all his personal needs and that of the 10 dependants. He will use his loan to buy fishing accessories, to replace his old and outmoded boat, and to replace his fishing net. He hopes to reinvest the new profit from his business.

loans.use: To buy fishing accessories

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy L., 39, is the mother of one child. She and her husband till a 3-hectare farm where they grow rice. They have been doing this since the start of their marriage. Currently, they have been irrigating their farm. They need additional financial assistance to pay the cost of land preparations.

She is asking a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She plans to buy fertilizer and other farming needs. She thinks that by doing so, she will be able to improve their harvest. 

CEVI helps small business grow. Many people are helped by the its wide range of services such as loans, trainings, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farming necessities

loans.name: Hodji

texts.ru: Ходжи женщина 48 лет. Замужем и имеет 4-х детей. Занимается откормом и продажей скота вместе с мужем. Ходжи откармливает скот дома, и когда скот будет готов, муж Ходжи продает их на скотном рынке. Ходжи кредитуется в нашей организации 1 год. Она успешно закончила два предыдущих займов, и теперь хочет взять очередной займ. Ходжи планирует увеличить количество своего скота и тем увеличить прибыль своей семьи. Ходжи очень нравится условия нашего кредитования, и она рада, что есть такие организации, поддерживающие общество.
texts.en:
Hodji is 48 years old, married and has 4 children. Together with her husband, she is involved in livestock feeding and sales. Hodji feeds the livestock at home, and once it is ready, Hodji’s husband sells the livestock at the livestock market. Hodji has been a client at our organization for 1 year. She successfully repaid two of her previous loans and now wants to obtain another one. Hodji plans to increase the quantity of her livestock and, subsequently, increase profit for her family. Hodji likes our financing terms, and she is happy that there are such organizations that support the public.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Mukaddas

texts.ru: Мукаддас 41 год. Она замужем и мать 3-х детей. Мукаддас занимается пошивом женской одежды на заказ. Она училась у хорошей швеи пол года. Теперь почти 7 лет она самостоятельно берет заказы и шьет разную женскую одежду, в том числе национальные платья, юбки, сорочки, брюки и т.д. Мукаддас берет кредит в нашей организации в первые. Она хочет приобрести импортную машину "Аверлог" для своего дела. Мукаддас надеется, что кредит поможет ей расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Mukaddas is 41 years old, married and has 3 children. Mukaddas is involved in sewing women’s clothing to-order. She learned from a good seamstress for half a year. Since then, she has been taking orders on her own for almost 7 years. She sews various women’s clothing, including traditional dresses, skirts, shirts, pants, etc. This is Mukaddas’s first time requesting a loan at our organization. She wants to purchase an imported sewing machine Averlog for her business. Mukaddas hopes that this loan will help her expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of the Averlog sewing machine

loans.name: Lala Dom

texts.fr: Monsieur A. est marié, pour subvenir à ses propres charges et à celles de sa femme, il a ouvert en 2007 une boutique qu’il a appelé « AFRIK SEL TOGO », l’activité qu’il exerce dans sa boutique est la vente de sel. Il s’approvisionne à Lomé et à Dakar. Il vend à des tenanciers de restaurant et à des bonnes dames. Voulant agrandir son commerce, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter  10 sacs de sel au Togo et 15 sacs de sel du sénégal.
texts.en:
Mr. A. is married and, to provide for his own needs and those of his wife, he opened a shop called AFRIK SEL TOGO in 2007. His shop sells salt and he gets his supplies in Lomé and Dakar. He sells to restaurant owners and to good women. Wishing to expand his business, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 10 bags of salt from Togo and 15 bags of salt from Senegal.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase salt

loans.name: Vision Katigume Elizabeth Group

texts.en: K. Elizabeth is 38 years old. She is a single mother of six children, all of whom attend school. She has a grocery business where she sells fresh food like cassava, sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, and so forth. She will use her loan to purchase grocery items such as cassava, sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes, bananas, and so forth, to meet her customers’ demand. She is an active and hardworking business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items

loans.name: Association Djigbode Group

texts.fr: Cette association a été crée par 6 femmes dynamiques, le but de l’association à sa création fut d’aider  financièrement ses membres. Elles se sont toutes convenues de se spécialiser dans une activité qui est la vente  de pagnes. Certaines disposent d’étalage, d’autres font ce commerce de façon ambulante. A la fin de chaque semaine l’association se réunit pour identifier les problèmes auxquelles certaines font face afin de l’aider. Voulant agrandir l’activité du groupe elle ont décidé d’un commun accord de solliciter de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 30 pièces de pagnes de différentes qualité. 3 de ses femmes sont mariées et mères de famille,les trois autres sont des femmes célibataires
texts.en:
This group was formed by 6 dynamic women and its founding goal was to help the members financially. They all decided to specialise in selling pagne (printed fabric). Some of them use display stands, others sell on foot. The group gets together at the end of each week to identify and solve any problems they encounter.
Wishing to expand the group’s business, they mutually agreed to request a loan from WAGES to purchase 30 lengths of pagne of different quality. Three of these women are married mothers and the other three are single.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pagne

loans.name: Vision Kabajuisa Beatrice Group

texts.en: K. Beatrice is a 40-year-old single mother of four children who are all in school. She also takes care of four other dependents. She has been dealing with livestock for over 10 years. She says transporting the animals is not easy. She is requesting a loan to purchase cows and goats for sale. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase cows and goats for sale.

loans.name: Ekiya

texts.en:
Ekiya M. sells green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and Irish potatoes to sell.  Ekiya is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. They have two children, both of whom are in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy beans and irish potatoes

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda A. is married and has 12 dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Matilda is a fishmonger who smokes fish and sells both fresh and smoked fish in Torkor near Kpando. She has been in this business since 2006. Her husband is a fisherman with a small canon that makes him catch fish in small quantity. 

Matilda is solely responsible for all the financial needs of herself and that of her 12 dependents. Matilda will use the loan to buy more fresh fish from other fisherman to smoke as a form of processing and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Matilda plans to reinvest.

loans.use: Matilda will use the loan to buy more fresh fish from other fisherman to smoke as a form of processing and sell

loans.name: Adizatu

texts.en:
Adizatu Y. is married and has five dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Adizatu sells provisions at Ashante Road in Cape Coast, something she has done since 1989 but on a smaller scale. Her husband is a commercial driver. 

Adizatu uses her income to pay for school fees, utility bills and clothing for her children and other expenses. Adizatu will use the loan to purchase more provisions to fill her store. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adizatu plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they plan to build for the family so that they can stop paying rent and also have enough rooms for their large family.

loans.use: Adizatu will use the loan to purchase more provisions to fill her store.

loans.name: Iheancho

texts.en:
C. sells sarongs, which can be used to make native wear and also tied around the waist by men and women. She also trades seasonal fruit as they become available. 

C. has been in business for the past seven years, and she is requesting a loan of N100,000 (US$675) to purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank N. is a 27-year-old single man. He lives in Kicukiro district in Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur owns a store selling phones and dishware in Kicukiro district and sells many types of mobile phones. Frank has many clients in his business, and now he is seeking his first loan worth 500,000 Rwf (US$900) from Vision Finance Company. He hopes to have many more clients after getting this loan, because he will increase the types of mobile phones in his store. Before this loan, Frank earned a monthly profit of US$366.

Frank has 2 years and 6 months of experience in this business. He starts his daily operations at 7:30 a.m. and closes at 9:30 p.m. 

With the increased profit, he will reinvest in the business and he hopes to buy a house.

loans.use: Expand his business

loans.name: Los Montones: Group 3

texts.en:
Martha S. R. (far left) is the coordinator for a group of five women seeking to take out a loan. She is a single mother of two children, ages 5 and 2. She manages a small business selling clothes, something she has a wealth of experience doing. 

This is the second time she has taken out a loan with Esperanza; her first loan was successfully used to expand her business to improve her family’s wellbeing. With this loan, she plans to purchase more clothes to further expand her business. Eventually, she hopes to open her own boutique.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Maymunatu

texts.en:
Maymunatu I. sells provisions in Cape Coast. Maymunatu has received no formal education. She is married and has three children. 

Maymunatu has been selling provisions for quite some time now. She is responsible for helping her husband to pay the rent, utility bills and other family financial expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for resale.

loans.name: Suweiba

texts.en:
Suweiba B. is married and has no children. She has no formal education. Suweiba sells provisions at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a commercial driver. 

Suweiba uses her income to support her husband in the housekeeping expenses. Suweiba will use the loan to purchase more provisions to fill her store. With the new profit from her expanded business, Suweiba plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to fill her store.

loans.name: Kipkemei Arap

texts.en: Mr. L. is 69 years old, married, and the father of six children. He has been in the brick-moulding business for the past three years. He intends to utilize this loan to assist him in hiring additional workers, to pay for water, and to buy firewood and grass for the preparation of bricks. These items will enable him to increase his current output and thus improve his income level. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase wood and grass for seasoning bricks

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora O. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high. Dora sells provisions at Brofoyedur in Cape Coast, which she has done since 2003. Her husband is a mobile phone dealer. 

Dora uses her income to support her husband with housekeeping expenses. Dora will use the loan to purchase provisions in bulk for retail. With the new profit from her expanded business, Dora plans to invest in the children so that they can gain a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase provisions in bulk for retail.

loans.name: Richard's Group

texts.en:
Richard A. is the leader of Buramba Tewtungye, a group in Bushenyi. He is a determined and dedicated 46-year-old man, who is married with three children aged 12 – 18 years. He also helps to care for two orphans. All of the children are in school. 

Richard has a bakery business that he inherited from his father 20 years ago. His market area is in the Ishaka suburbs,  with Mitooma secondary school and the University nearby. His main challenge has been the constant increase in price of the raw materials, such as flour and oil. He uses his motorcycle to supply the products to his customers and this makes his work a bit easier. 

His kind of products include doughnuts, cookies, brown bread, pancakes, kebab and chapattis and luckily he has customers for all his products. Richard had a dream of opening up a store in the suburban town with a van to expand in the market, as well as have all his children educated up to the university level. He needs a loan to help with buying firewood and flour for baking purposes.

loans.use: Buying firewood and flour for baking purposes.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. sells powdered fish and shrimp at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Elizabeth has received no formal education.  She is married and has one child. Her husband is a trader in electronics. 

Elizabeth has been selling powdered fish and shrimp since 2003. She is responsible for paying utility bills, food and school fees for her child. Her loan will be used to buy more powdered fish and shrimp for resale. She hopes to use the new profit from her business to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To buy more powdered fish and shrimp for resale.

loans.name: Equator Kyotukire Molly Group

texts.en:
K. Molly is 25 years old and married with one child and also takes care of one dependent who attends school. She has been running her retail business for a year. She is using the loan to purchase items such as sodas, sugar, salt, soap, match boxes, etc., for her retail shop. 

She is expanding on her business for more profit. She believes in growing her business, and she is a living example to others in the community. Her hope for the future is to educate her child and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sodas, sugar, salt, soap, match boxes, etc., for her retail shop.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. sells food supplies like onions, beans, groundnut, maize and others at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Felicia has received a junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a carpenter. 

Felicia has been selling food supplies like beans, groundnut, maize and others since 2001. She is responsible for helping her husband pay school fees for the children and also the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more groundnut, beans, millet and maize in larger quantities for distribution to her customers. She hopes to use the new profit from her business to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To buy more groundnut, beans, millet and maize in larger quantities for distribution to her customers.

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is divorced with two grown children. She sells women's clothing.  Oksana has been in this business for 10 years. She used to work as an engineer. After downsizing, she became unemployed and decided to try to open a business. 

She got a kiosk that was located close to the central food market. It helped her to catch many clients who go to the food market. Even today there is very little competition at this particular location. It helps Oksana to have good sales. 

Using HOPE loans, Oksana recently opened a second location. Oksana would like to borrow 11,000 UAH (US$1,450) to purchase more inventory. Oksana has a goal -- to help her daughter purchase a separate apartment.

loans.use: To purchase women's shorts and T-shirts

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose M. is married and has four dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Rose sells clothing and fabric at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast, which she has done since 1984. Her husband is on pension. 

Rose uses her income to help her husband pay school fees for the children and also pay the rent and utility bills. Rose will use the loan to purchase clothing and fabric in large quantities for resale. With the new profit from her expanded business, Rose plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and fabric in large quantities for resale.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. sells food supplies like beans, groundnut and others at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Comfort has received no formal education.  She is married and has two children. 

Comfort has been selling food supplies like beans, groundnut and others since 1989, but has been doing it on a smaller scale. She is responsible for helping her husband with paying school fees for the children and also paying the utility bills. Her loan will be used to increase the quantity of beans and groundnuts and for her transportation cost since she travels to a very distant farming town called Techiman to buy the food supplies. 

She hopes to use the new profit from her business to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of beans and groundnuts and for her transportation cost

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en:
Celestina Q. is married and has one child. She has received schooling through junior high. Celestina sells silverware and other cooking utensils at Zion in Cape Coast, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is a trader. 

Celestina uses her income to pay for her child's school fees, clothing, utility bills and other family expenses. Celestina will use the loan to purchase more goods, including silverware and cooking utensils for resale. With the new profit from her expanded business, Celestina plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To purchase more goods, including silverware and cooking utensils for resale.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina K. is married and has four dependents. She has no formal education. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Angelina sells Silva plates, groceries, fabrics and buckets at Zion in Cape Coast, which she has done since 2000. Angelina uses her income to pay for school fees for the children, clothing, utility bills and other family expenses. She will use the loan to purchase more Silva plates, fabrics and buckets for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to put up for the family.

loans.use: To purchase more Silva plates, fabrics and buckets to sell

loans.name: Kellen's Group

texts.en:
M. Kellen is the group leader of Byeshembe. She is 36 years old, married, and has five children. In addition, she also takes care of her three sisters.

Kellen is involved in the tailoring business - she buys new textiles for sale and sewing, mostly for secondary schools, such as Kazo secondary, Buremba secondary, Kazo model secondary, St. Catherine secondary, and Kyabahura Primary school, all of which are in Kellen's locality.

With her previous loans, Kellen has already been able to buy two sewing machines, a flat iron and an overlock machine that have helped her in the tailoring business by making her work look neat and professional. Kellen needs a loan to buy more materials for sewing.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials for tailoring

loans.name: Equator Nakato Geradina Group

texts.en:
N. Geradina is 34 years old and married with six children, of whom four are going to school.

She has been running a butcher business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase goats to sell goat meat in her butcher shop. She is a courageous lady who believes in managing any kind of business so long as it is income-generating. Her future hope is to purchase a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase goats so as to sell goat meat in her butcher shop

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia S. H. is married and has four dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Cecilia S. sells used clothing at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast, which she has done since 1995. Her husband is a trader. 

Cecilia S. uses her income to pay for school fees for the children, clothing, utility bills and other family expenses. She will use the loan to purchase more used clothing for resale. With the new profit from her expanded business, Cecilia S. plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothing for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. sells doughnuts, which are normally served with porridge and eaten as breakfast in Zion in Cape Coast. Rose has received a junior high education.  She is married and has six dependents. 

Rose has been selling doughnuts since 1999. She is responsible for paying the children's school fees, clothing, utility bills and other family expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more flour, sugar, vegetable oil and other ingredients to enable her to increase the production of doughnuts. She hopes to use the new profit from her business to support her husband in saving towards acquiring a piece of land on which to build a house for the family.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar, vegetable oil and other ingredients to enable her to increase doughnut production

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Greetings from Jean Damascene N., a 28-year-old married man with three children ages, 7, 4 and 2. He and his family live in Kicukiro District in Kigali city the capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur does his business in Kicukiro district, where he sells the old scrap metal of cars to other entrepreneurs who produce tools. Jean Damascene started his business two years ago and now is seeking his first loan worth 500,000 Rwf (US$900) from Vision Finance Company. He employs two regular workers in his business, and his business enables him to have a monthly profit of US$550. He works from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. every day. With this loan, he intends to buy more scrap, and with the increased profit he will pay school fees for his children and continue to reinvest in the same business.

loans.use: Buy more scrap metal

loans.name: Hagar

texts.en:
Hagar K. is married and has four dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Hagar sells provisions and hair products at Zion in Cape Coast, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a sprayer. 

Hagar uses her income to pay for school fees for her children, clothing, utility bills and other family expenses. Hagar will use the loan to purchase hair products and provisions in bulk for sale. With the new profit from her expanded business, Hagar plans to support her husband in saving towards a house they want to build for the family.

loans.use: To purchase hair products and provisions in bulk.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Greetings from Beatrice M., a 41-year-old married woman with five children, ages 18, 16, 13, 11 and 9. She and her family live in Nyarugenge district in Kigali city the capital of Rwanda.

M. runs her business in Nyarugenge district, where she owns a small printer and produces postcards, invitation cards and more. Beatrice is seeking her first loan worth 500,000 Rwf (US$900) from Vision Finance Company to buy another printing machine. 

This entrepreneur has six years of experience and employs three people who help her in running the business smoothly. She starts her business at 8:00 a.m. and closes at 6:00 p.m. every day.

This business enables Beatrice to have a monthly profit of $1,000, and with the increased profit she hopes to pay school fees for her children and continue to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy a printing machine

loans.name: Equator Mutabazi Jane Group

texts.en: M. Jane is a married businesswoman, age 48, blessed with eight children in school and looking after three more children going to school. She has been rearing poultry for two months. She is using this loan to purchase chicks, chicken feed, etc. She is a hardworking woman whose dream is to open up a shop in Kasese town.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, chicken feed, etc.

loans.name: Los Montones: Group 2

texts.en: Dinorah D. L. C. is the coordinator for a group of five women seeking to take out a loan. She is married with eight children, ranging in age from 14 to 35. She makes her living selling bedspreads and cushions. Dinorah plans to use her loan to buy better materials to improve the quality of her product and grow her business. She has taken out multiple loans in the past, but this will be her biggest loan yet.

loans.use: More and higher quality business inputs, such as fabric to make bedspreads

loans.name: Annah's Group

texts.en:
T. Annah is a hardworking and bold lady and the leader of Akatongore group in Ibanda. Annah has had a business rearing goats in Akatongore village for the past three years . The main business challenge is accessing drugs for her animals. She is able to make ~70,000 profit per week and is able to look after her children and pay their school fees.

Annah is also a farmer, though on a small scale. The food helps to feed her children and the excess is sold for income. She has a dream of buying more goats and growing more crops so as to turn into a modern farmer with more profits from more customers. She needs a loan to be able to buy more goats and to employ labor on her farm.

loans.use: To buy more goats and employ labor on her farm

loans.name: Mtazamo Group

texts.en:
Yusuph Abul, age 26, is married with one child of 5 months. He sells telephones. He started his business in 2005.  He works daily from 7 a.m. until 8 p.m. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $168.

This will be Yusuph’s sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase his voucher stock and to start selling telephones and has repaid the loans successfully.  He wants a new loan to improve and renovate the shop where he sells his vouchers and telephones.
 	
Yusuph will share this loan with his loan group, Mtazamo which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Yusuph is second from the left, second row.

loans.use: To repair and expand the shop for his business.

loans.name: La Solución Group

texts.en:
Carmen G. (second from right) is a member of La Solución--a group of entrepreneurs from the city of Samaná, Dominican Republic. She has two children who are 9 years old and 2 years old. The two year old is pictured here with her. This is Carmen’s very first loan and she is excited about beginning a business selling clothing and shoes to those in her neighborhood.

Carmen hopes that with time her business will grow and the profits will help her make a better life for her family. She currently lives in a rented house with her husband, who is a construction worker. The two of them hope that the additional income from Carmen’s business will allow them to move into a house of their own. Carmen’s husband is supporting her endeavor and they are both excited about the opportunities that the profits from Carmen’s business will bring to their family. Carmen and her family are thankful for any help you can offer!

loans.use: To buy clothing and shoes

loans.name: Evans Muhazi

texts.en: Evans Muhazi is a businessman who runs a retail shop which majors in household goods in Vihiga town. His clientele comes from Mbale market. Evans was introduced to KADET by an existing client at the time and took a first loan of Kshs 20,000 ($257). Evans is married with two children and his wife is currently helping him run the business. He has experienced growth in his business and plans to add more stock. With the new loan, he hopes to expand the business and thus increase revenue, and as a result improve the status of his family. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of household items for his shop

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en: Uuganbayar G. is 25 years old and is just married. In May 2008, he bought bicycle repair equipment for 1,700,000 tugrugs ($1,200 USD) and started repairing bicycles; he rents a small room at the central local market for his shop. Uuganbayar not only repairs bicycles bur also sells new bicycles. Before fall comes, he is planning to expand his business and purchase more bicycles from the capital city, Ulaanbaatar, where he goes every two months to purchase bicycles and spare parts at  very cheap prices. His wife Batchimeg works as a saleswoman at a local food stall and is paid 150,000 ($110 USD) tugrugs per month. With this loan, he will purchase a variety of bicycles at wholesale prices to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts and new bicycles

loans.name: Wayna Ccapac Group

texts.es:
Los socios son del banco comunal “WAYNA CCAPAC”, ellos son 10 miembros, residentes D. Urubamba, ubicado en pleno corazón del valle sagrado D. los inkas, en la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestros socios, alternas sus actividades D. costumbre con el comercio minorista, ellos desean solicitar este préstamo en razón a sus necesidades D. implementar sus pequeños negocios como el D. tiendas abarrotes, con productos al por mayor D. arroz, azúcar, fideos, aceites y otros y otro grupo D. socios utilizarán el préstamo para comprar todo lo referente a la venta D. chicha D. maíz amarillo, para esto ellos desean los diferentes montos.

Ellos se encuentran agradecidos con este medio. Por la oportunidad brindada y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago total D. sus deudas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the “WAYNA CCAPAC” Microfinance Institute resiD. in the heart of the Sacred Valley of the Incas, in the city of Cusco.

Our members alternate their traditional customs with their small businesses. They would like to request this loan so that they may restock their general stores with wholesale products like rice, sugar, noodles, cooking oil, and other goods. Some of the other members will use their loan to purchase everything related to chicha (a traditional beverage derived from corn) sales, such as yellow corn. This is why they need different amounts of money.

They are very grateful to this institute for the opportunity that they have been given, and they committed to repaying their debts within the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods for general store and chicha sales

loans.name: Obasi

texts.en: U. has a big depot where she sells drinks; she gets her supply directly from the manufacturing company. She started this business a year ago; before that she sold sarongs. U. is 46 years old, married and has five children.  She needs a loan of N120,000 to purchase more drinks. She promises to pay back the loan and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Ojelabi

texts.en: J. sells foodstuffs. She has been in this business for eight years. She is requesting a loan amount of N160,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. J. has been borrowing from LAPO for over three years. She is 54 years old and is married with two children.  She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuff to sell

loans.name: Olufunsho

texts.en: E. is the headmistress of a primary school in the Ikotun area of Lagos. She also has a shop where she sells washing soaps of all kinds. She has two sales attendants who assist her in the trade. E. gets her supply of goods directly from the various manufacturing companies, at a discount. She started this business five years ago. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more soap to sell. With her paid job and this business E. assists her husband in providing for the needs of the family as he does not have a stable job. E. is 40 years old and has four children.

loans.use: To purchase more soap to sell

loans.name: Sangita

texts.en:
Sarita S. and her husband own a small plot of land that they use to grow maize and a variety of vegetables, including cauliflower, broccoli and carrots. They also raise animals, including one buffalo, one cow and several goats.

Sarita's husband  works with her on the farm. They have two sons, one who is in grade one at school and one who is a toddler.

Sarita is applying for a loan of Rs. 10, 000 to buy more animals and food for her animals. She hopes to be able to sell the milk produced by the animals and, if she buys young animals, she can sell them when they reach adulthood.

Usually this time of year, typically referred to as ‘monsoon season’ in Nepal, there is a lot of rain and it is the best time for planting and growing crops. Unfortunately there has been very little rain so far and people working in agriculture are becoming increasingly concerned.

Sarita hopes that with the help of a Kiva loan, she will have a bit more financial security and even if her crops do not grow as well as they do most years, she will have been able to invest in her livestock as an alternative.

loans.use: new animals and food to feed the animals

loans.name: Toluani

texts.en: Toluani makes adire (a native kind of clothes worn by Nigerians), patterned in accordance with choice and culture. She has been in this business for seven years. She is requesting for the loan of 120,000 nairas to purchase chemicals for adire-making. Toluani is 26 years old and has been borrowing from LAPO for over two years. She says thank you!

loans.use: To purchase chemicals for adire-making

loans.name: Thuli

texts.en:
Thuli T. grows vegetables and maize on a small plot of land near her house. Usually, at this time of year--typically referred to as ‘monsoon season’ in Nepal--there is a lot of rain and it is the best time for planting and growing crops. Unfortunately there has been very little rain so far and people working in agriculture are becoming increasingly concerned.

Thuli has a big family with five daughters and one son. All of her children are married now except for one daughter. Her daughter and her son and his wife live together with Thuli and her husband. Thuli’s son helps her with the farm each day because Thuli’s husband works as a security guard in a different town.

Thuli is applying for a loan of 10,000 Nepal rupees to purchase new seedlings for her farm. Thuli hopes that the loan will help her to grow more vegetables and maize this year so that she can make a greater contribution to her family’s income.

loans.use: To buy more seedlings to grow vegetables

loans.name: Ashogbon

texts.en: S. sells sand and gravel for house building. She gets her goods from the Lagos lagoon and the sandbar beach, from a boat service at the riverside. Then she uses a tipper or truck to supply her customers. She started this business eight years ago. She is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more sand. S. is 36 years old and is married with four children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more sand and gravel to sell

loans.name: Thuli

texts.en:
Thuli M. and her husband own a plot of land in their village of Dulchoky, Nepal. They use the land to grow vegetables, which they sell at the local market or in the city of Patan.

Thuli is applying for a loan of Rs. 10, 000 to purchase new seedlings for her vegetable farm.

Thuli has three sons and one daughter and is happy that she can make an equal contribution to her family’s living expenses.

Some of Thuli’s produce is sold in Patan, a city that takes two hours to reach by car from Thuli’s farm. A vegetable seller comes every few days to Thuli’s town and purchases vegetables from her and her neighbors to sell in Patan. In the future Thuli would like to sell the vegetables herself in Patan, because then she could make a bigger profit.

Thuli hopes that her Kiva loan will help her to expand her farming business and create more opportunities for her and her family.

loans.use: to purchase vegetable seedlings

loans.name: Unida En Accion Group

texts.en:
Esperanza G. is a budding entrepreneur who would like nothing more than to expand her business. Currently, she operates out of her house selling many things, such as women’s clothing, cooking equipment, and baked goods. Through Esperanza’s ambition she organized four other local women from the community into a group in order to approach Esperanza for a loan.

Esperanza is a single mother raising three children. She has two boys, aged thirteen and eight, and one 3 year old daughter. When talking to Esperanza, it was very clear that her family is the number one priority for her, and she would do anything to make sure they were happy. Currently, the two boys are in school and they are doing well, and she would love nothing more than for them to attend college in the future. The three year old daughter is a handful, but is always smiling.

Obtaining a loan is what Esperanza needs in order to expand her business. Along with the ability to expand her inventory, she would like to purchase a cart with which she could travel around her village to sell her goods. In order to sell now, she has to stay in her house, but with a cart it will open up a whole new market of potential customers. The opportunity for obtaining a loan is a very rare opportunity for these women, and all members of the group, not only Esperanza, stressed their intentions to work very hard in order to pay the loan back in the allotted time.

loans.use: clothing, kitchen equipment, and bakery products.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: T. is 29 years old; she sells phone recharge cards in large quantities, as she has a printing machine. She has been in this business since 2002 and is doing fine. T. is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more material for printing. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase material for printing rechargeable cards to sell

loans.name: Huruma Group

texts.en:
Abeid Y., age 45, is married with three children ages 12, 3 and 6 years. He has had a tailoring business since 1990. He works daily from 7 am to 8 pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of about $301.

This will be Abeid’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants a loan to buy more materials for his tailoring business.  

Abeid will share this loan with his group, Huruma, which totals 22 members. These members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Abeid is second from left, front row.

loans.use: To buy more materials for making clothing.

loans.name: Setimaya

texts.en:
Setimaya L. works with her husband growing vegetables on a small plot of land in their village, Dolchoky, Nepal.

Setimaya is applying for a loan of Rs. 10, 000 to purchase new vegetable seedlings for her farm.

Usually this time of year in Nepal, typically referred to as ‘monsoon season’, there is a lot of rain and it is the best time for planting and growing crops. Unfortunately there has been very little rain so far and Setimaya is concerned that her produce will not sell as well as last year. Setimaya says that already some of her vegetables have been spoiled because they haven’t gotten enough water.

Setimaya has four daughters and one son. She hopes that from the income made by selling vegetables, she can provide her children with a good quality education.

loans.use: purchasing vegetable seedlings

loans.name: Udor

texts.en: T. sells cooking oil. She is requesting a loan of N140,000 to purchase more drums of oil to sell. She promises to pay back the loan in eight equal installments. T. is 43 years old, has three children and is a widow. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drums of oil to sell

loans.name: Kishna

texts.en:
Kishna K. works on a small plot of land growing vegetables and maize with the help of one of her sons. Kishna and her husband both used to work on the land but he is too elderly now for physical labour.

Kishna is applying for a loan of Rs. 10, 000 to purchase new seedlings for her vegetable farm.

Every few days Kishna’s son travels from their village of Dolchoky to Kathmandu to sell their produce. It is very expensive to reach Kathmandu,  sometimes taking more than four hours of travel time in a day,  but Kishna and her family receive more money for their vegetables if they sell them at the market themselves.

Kishna has three sons, only one of whom is still in school. Kishna finds the manual labor on her farm very tiring and hopes that in the future all of her sons will join the family farming business so that she can retire with her husband.

loans.use: purchasing vegetable seedlings

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: A. sells tailoring material and clothes and she also sews clothes. A. is 33 years old and is married with 3 children. She is requesting a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more clothes and tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and tailoring materials

loans.name: Ogunfowora

texts.en: A. rents out VCDs. She is 27 years old and married with 2 children. She is requesting a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more VCDs to rent. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Sancha

texts.en:
Sancha M. B. owns the only medium-sized shop in her village and she stocks everything imaginable, from rice to running shoes to the red bangles worn by many of the women in Nepal.

Sancha is applying for a Kiva loan of Rs. 10,000 that she will use to purchase more items for her shop. Sancha says that she particularly needs to buy comfortable, affordable sandal-style shoes and more rice, as these are the most popular items in her shop.

Sancha has two daughters, one son and a husband, all of whom help her out in the shop. Sancha says that she and her husband make all of their business decisions together, including the decision to take out a Kiva loan.

In the future Sancha hopes that she can continue to expand her business and begin supplying stock to smaller shops in the area. She would like to be able to provide her children with a very good quality education so that they can pursue whichever career they think will make them happy.

loans.use: more stock for the grocery store including shoes and rice

loans.name: Bikamwa Plus Group

texts.fr: Véronique T. vend du maїs et du manioc devant sa parcelle. Le riz et le haricot étaient les premiers produits alimentaires qu’elle a vendus en 1979. Au fil des années, Véronique a acquit une expérience solide dans cette activité.
